title: Modified (6/10 inch) Airboat Mount for Speed Boat 3

description.text:
A remix of the airboat mount at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:930577. This allows you to mount the motor in such a way that the direction of the fan can be changed with a servo and thus requires no rudder.

There are two versions - 6" and 10". The 10" offers more speed and I've mostly conquered stability issues from the extra weight and thrust. The v2 edition rotates the motor 180 degrees in order to move the center of gravity forward as well as allow you to mount a standard 1045 prop in standard (rather than reversed) direction.

V1 flood test: https://youtu.be/-YAwS18ASvo
V2 pond test: https://youtu.be/dRFjIa6UuYU

Steering is controlled with two springs attached to the servo and the motor mount in order to control the direction.

title: Tamiya Alpine A110 Battery Tray Adapter and Cover
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
An adapter to fit 2200 2s LiPo batteries in the Tamiya Alpine M-06S battery bay.
It is held in place with 8 short M3 screws, filling the vacant holes in the underside of the chassis.
Battery is positioned forward for more nose weight, and there is a hole for keeping the balance lead out of harms way.
Also included is a replacement battery strap which covers the battery, preventing water and muck getting in. It has a zip-tie point for a LiPo alarm, and a handle for easy removal.

There are two options, one with a hole and matching notch for mounting the antenna next to the reciever (for 2.4Ghz recievers with short antennas), and one set without.

The battery used is a Giant Power 2200mAh 35C LiPo from https://www.componentshop.co.uk/

Battery Dimensions are approx. 104 x 35.5 x 18mm
If you have an M3 tap, it would be a good idea to thread the holes for easier screw insertion.

description.text:

The cover prevents such. Just slide it over and you're done, add a few adhesive if you want to be absolutely sure it does not take off mid-print (no must-have).

As an extra benefit you get a useful end-stop when attaching your plate back on.

author: Timo15

print_settings.Notes:: When printing using a semi-transparent filament I also recommend using five top layers on the front and five bottom layers on the bottom, unless you really want the see the fill pattern.

description.text:
The SmartKEY Pocket Organizer is an incredibly simple way to organise the keys in your pocket with the jagged teeth of the keys cutting into your trousers, or causing a tangle. It was inspired by the original KeySmart (https://getkeysmart.com), a Swiss Army like key organiser.

The SmartKEY is very easy and *fast' to print. In less than an hour you should have the components to put together your very own Pocket Organizer. As opposed to all other Swiss Army key organisers I've come across, every part of the SmartKEY is 3D-printed. No need for any extra screws or nuts.

The SmartKEY is simple, yet very versatile. I've so far made bolts that allow anywhere between two to eight keys. It would be very easy to make larger versions since the size only depends on the length of the bolts.

The SmartKEY comprises a front and a back and two bolts. It's really that simple. The size of the bolts decides the thickness of the SmartKey and therefore how many keys, or accessories, it can hold.

Suggested sizes:
2 keys - 5mm screws
4 keys - 7mm screws
6 keys - 11mm screws
8 keys - 15mm screws

If the keys you have seem to be either to thick or too narrow for one of these length screws to work properly, or if you need space between your keys to get them to move the way you want, print an appropriate number of SmartKey_Key_Distance and use in between your keys to build out the width until it fits with an appropriate screw length.

There are two versions each of the front and the back. The front versions are either plain - nothing printed on the front - or the standard one with SmartKey printed on it. The back versions are with or without a key ring hoop "built in".

If you have an uneven number of keys or accessories I recommend printing the back without the hoop and print the SmartKey_Hoop_Addon accessory, which effectively takes up one key slot.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Finder

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.18mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

To make the screws as tough as possible I printed using 5 perimeters.

When printing using a semi-transparent filament I also recommend using five top layers on the front and five bottom layers on the bottom, unless you really want the see the fill pattern.

Preparing for assembly

The trick to assembling the SmartKEY is to make sure the screws and nuts are reasonably well threaded, which they normally are not as they come off the bed. To do that the best way seems to be to gently screw a screw into a nut, and twist it around in both directions until it moves smoothly.

After having torn off multiple screws in the nuts of the back on a couple of occasions I created a screw as well as a nut tester to avoid this happening again. I suggest printing these first and "calibrating" them on each other by screwing the nut tester into the screw tester until the screw spins effortlessly on the nut threads.

Once you've printed the actual screws, "calibrate" them in the screw tester by carefully screwing them in and out of the tester until they move effortlessly. Us the nut tester in a similar fashion on the nuts in the back piece.

If you do this you should have no problem assembling the SmartKEY when all pieces have printed.

Assembling the SmartKEY

To assemble the SmartKEY, simply place the first key you want to add onto the nut on one side of the SmartKEY. If you need to you can place a distance on top of it.

Put the screw in the corresponding whole in the front piece. Then put the rest of the keys, with distances in between if you need to, onto the screw, until only the threaded part of the screw sticks out.

Place the top with the keys on the bottom part, aligning it so that the tip of the screw is right on top of the nut. With the screw straight and pressed against the nut, press the front and the keys downward to allow the screw to come out slightly of the depression in the front plate, making it easier to screw it in with your fingers.

Gently turn the screw until you get traction in the nut, then screw it in with your fingers as far as it goes. Once it's in as far as you can make it, use a flat screw driver or similar to tighten gently.

When the first screw is in, twist the front to the side so you can place the first key on the second nut and repeat the process for the other side of the SmartKEY.

author: korcaliskan

print_settings.Notes:: The tops clip onto the chassis with a snap fit design, so no glue or post processing is necessary.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
I challenged myself over Christmas break to come up with a two axle chassis with spinning wheels that can be printed without support and without post assembly.

I also wanted it to have a bounce to the suspension. After about 8 iterations this is what I came up with. I designed a car and a truck to sit on the chassis.

I tried to make it so that the chassis took 3 hours to print and the car took 3 hours to print. The truck top takes about 4 hours because it is slightly larger.

This was printed on my Maker Select V2, with an all metal hotend.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.16

Infill:

30

Notes:

The smaller the resolution, the more lines in the hood due to the slight angle.

The chassis doesn't need a brim or support but is less stringy with supports and it only adds about 30min.

The car top and truck top need supports. (touching build plate). They were designed to be printed with the top facing up. The Car file needs to be flipped around.

The tops clip onto the chassis with a snap fit design, so no glue or post processing is necessary.

Top Coat

For the green car and truck in the image, I printed out the part in grey and coated in XTC-3D from smooth-on. It self levels on the part (doesn't actually melt the plastic) making it smooth to the touch but you still see the ridges. I added a drop of green oil paint to the epoxy giving the translucent color seen in the image. It took about 2 hours to dry to the touch.

comments.text: How can the tops print without supports? Seems like the car would have problems that would be very visible on the outside and the truck would have issues that are not visible on the inside. Do you really print the car upside down like that?

Notes:

Even with my "large & fast" settings, it still takes 11 hours to print.

The stock part cooling fan is not adequate. I want stronger airflow for better cooling so I thought a twin 5015 will be more than sufficient. This was created with Autodesk 123D Design. I sliced it with CURA and printed with green PLA at 210 C. Print it with the logo and wordings side on the bottom.

  1. Remove the stock cooling fan and snip the wires. Make sure the printer is off.
  2. Solder the wires from the two 5015 fans in parallel to the stock fan wires. Take of the polarity red to red and black to black. Put heat shrink tubing over the soldered joints. The 5015 fans are 24 volts.
  3. Remove the four screws from the extruder fan and ease the printed twin fan ducts onto the extruder housing. It is a little tight.
  4. The four screws can be put back to secure the fan ducts to housing. Do not over tighten or it will strip the threads in the extruder fan.
  5. Slot the two 5015 fans into the ducts and secure them with a bit of super glue.

I found the two 5015 fans to be very strong but they vibrate a lot so I balanced them as follows. You can use this method to balance any of the fans in the printer including those in the control box.

  1. Remove the fan from the mounting, put it standing on a hard flat surface and turn it on. If you see it gyrating on the surface making noise, it is not balanced.
  2. To balance it, just cut a small strip of double sided tape (those transparent real sticky ones with red backing) and just stick it randomly on one point on the fan hub.
  3. Turn it on and see if the gyrations and noise reduce. If it does you are spot on. If not just move the tape slightly to the left or right until it does. Need a bit of patience to get it right.
  4. To make it permanent, you can put a blob of epoxy where the tape is. I didn't bother doing this because so far the tapes held.
  5. Do remember to use a pencil to mark the position in case the tape flies off.

description.text:
This is a screw driver for m3 Nuts if you havebigger or smaler nuts, you can calculate the fitting scale in your slicer

m4 = 133.3333%

m(x) = 33.33333333 * x

x is the mm diameter of your nut (m4 = 4 mm)

Then you get the factor to type in in your slicer.

Assembly:

If you want to catch a nut, sometimes it helps to pull the rod tool little bit upwards.

If you want to get the nut out of the tool push it inwards

description.text:
PunkOTTO+

I was in search for a cool project to do with Arduino Microcontroller and I came across this little robot Otto+ .

Although there is detailed information on how to build one in the above link I found it quite confusing with the variety of the files versions and decided to bring here a clear version that works for me with some modification I made and include:

  1. New head to fit better the sound sensor, Ultrasonic sensor, Arduino nano+Shield with holes to Voltage and mini usb
  2. New Body with customize space for on/off switch, USB charger,18650 Li-Ion battery and LED matrix
Just to clarify that I'm not the owner of the Arduino files, App and the idea ownership is from the link above

To build PunkOTTO+ you will need the following:

  • 1 pcs Arduino nano

  • 1 pcs Arduino nano shield

  • 1 pcs Led Matrix

  • 1 pcs Mini USB charger or this for Micro USB

  • 1 pcs Samsung 18650 30Q 3000MaH Li-Ion rechargeable battery

  • 1 pcs Set of Jumper wires

  • 1 pcs On/off switch

  • 1 pcs HC-06 Bluetooth Module

  • 1 pcs 20Awg Silicon wire

  • 4 pcs MG90 metal servo

  • 1 pcs Buzzer

Tools you will need to build PunkOTTO+:

  • 3D printer to print your parts, I use: Tevo Tornado

  • 3D printer filament, I use ABS from: HATCHBOX

  • Highly recommended: Soldering station

  • Soldering free hands

  • Hot glue gun 150W

  • Magnetic screw driver set

Steps to build PunkOTTO+

  1. Download 3D files and print them

  2. Follow Parts assembling instructions

  3. Follow Fritzing wiring scheme from fritzing file or PDF

  4. Download Arduino IDE and install it

  5. Download OttoDIYAPP_121.zip Extract the zip and install the APK file in your Android phone

  6. Upload the Libraries from the zip to Arduino IDE - Don't know how? Follow this

  7. Open OttoDIYAPP_121.ino with Arduino IDE search for the line Serial.begin(19200); and change it to the baud rate on your HC-06 Bluetooth module! If you didnt touch it from factory the default is 9600. So change it from 19200 to 9600. It should look now Serial.begin(9600). compile and upload it to your Arduino

  8. Now enable your mobile Bluetooth and search for HC-06, pair it!

  9. Open the App in your mobile and press "Find Otto+" on the blue bar, search for your HC-06 and connect Enjoy (:

author: UniversalMaker

description.text: So I had a request from my brother for a raspberry pi case that would fit the raspberry pi with an XBee hat stacked on top. After searching thingiverse, I did not find anything that fit the bill. The next best thing was to throw together a design. This case is pretty basic with plain square corners, but it should do the job. I did not have the pi and hat to take measurements from, so some of this was just guessing. Feel free to modify it as needed.

The Basics

So to make this, I needed a starting point. My main tool for the design was OpenSCAD. I did a search on thingiverse for any Raspberry Pi files for OpenSCAD. I found the Raspberry Pi 3 Hull designed by hilderonny which is basically a block layout of the Raspberry Pi 2B or 3 that can be used to design cases. The basic idea is to design your case and subtract the hull which will cut all the necessary holes for ports and such. I had to make some very slight modifications to hilderonny's design to make things fit my case, so I included the modified design in my files.

The Case

For the design of the case, noting fancy was needed, so it is just a basic square box design. I was told that the only thing going in the case was the Raspberry Pi with the XBee hat with no external connections needed other than the wires for the Pi. Because of this, there are no other external holes for wires and such. I did however include some venting slots at the top of the case. The bottom has holes for screws that can be fed through and screwed into the standoffs that hold the XBee hat in place. This will secure the Pi to the bottom case. The cover simply snaps into 2 channels cut in the upper edge of the bottom case section. The first prototype of the case fit together nice and snug with no play.

Feel free to make any modifications to this design. I have it listed as a work in progress, but don't plan on making any modifications unless under special request.

I found that reliably throwing the F1 when using a 4s 2200mah was nearly impossible. I use a bungee launch for my bigger wings ( Opterra, Z3, RV Jet). Bungee Launching allows for a stress free launch 100% of the time. Obviously, this replaces the entire bottom plate on the F1. I used ShoeGoo to glue it in place.

remixed_from.title: Clamp On Spool Holder for 1KG Spools

description.text:
A spool holder clamp for shelves up to 25mm thick.
Adapted from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2203997, reinforced and redesigned.
Added a rubber layer for the clamp and rubber ending for the screw, so it creates more friction in the shelf, avoiding that it slides off or damages the shelf itself. The rubber files should be printed in flexible material.
Also designed a smaller clamp for smaller filament spools.
It should be printed with support in a strong material like ABS or PETG, with walls thicker than 1mm and infill higher than 30%.
It should also be printed in the position provided in the STL for resistance purposes, which should avoid layer separations due to the weight of the filament spool.

description.text:
An Interesting "Spin" on a Vase

New Tools in My Belt

In my continuing quest to learn new tools and techniques, I set out to learn OnShape and create something perhaps a little different than my usual fare.

I've always wanted to create a "Twist Vase" of sorts so I set out to do this in OnShape.

After some experiments, this is the result I came up with. Its two opposing twists which led to something that reminded me of intertwining sinew. Asymmetry on one plane and symmetry on another leads to an effect that triggers a feeling somewhere between chaos and order.

It is possible for this to hold water, though you may need a bigger nozzle in combination with shorter layer heights.

For an example of the vase holding water, see this silly video: https://youtu.be/WcyIUXXModY

Printer:

Bobs CNC RP9 v2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4mm

Infill:

None

Notes:

To maximize the chance that the vessel will hold liquid, I encourage you to use a larger nozzle diameter (I used 0.8mm) and a shorter layer height (0.2mm-0.4mm). In doing so, you will ensure layers will overlap more as the printer prints the spiral.

Higher temperatures for PLA along with slower speeds and good cooling will also maximize layer adhesion while preserving surface finish. I actually pushed the temperature up to 240C and kept the speed around 30mm/s. Part cooling fans were off for the base layers then on at 40% after the base layers. Each printer is unique so you may need to adjust parameters on yours to get the best result.

Also, this particular vase is made up of two bodies. I have had no issues slicing in Cura, although it is possible that the model may need to be repaired for some slicers to work with it. I will likely be checking it out with Meshmixer soon and upload a repaired model if necessary.
If I get around to making a tutorial, I will place a link to it here. Take my methods with a grain of salt - they are not necessarily the best.

A jar cap for ikea jar

This started out as

Bed Leveling Attachments by by maker311
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:911364

But the clips didn't work on my print head by virtue of the side fan, and custom duct. So I created a single object to hold the leveler in place, and allow me to slide it around on the rails (on the magnets) freely. Further, when you begin leveling on the Powerspec, the head goes home which makes clipping the leveler in place only possible after the head has gone to the first position.

I use a rubber band to firmly hold the level in the mount, and it is very accurate, and very easy to level the bed now.

I printed it on raft, and with supports, which Simplify3D does extremely well, very easy to remove.
Very happy with it, and thanks to maker311 for the original design.

I had to build my own tool because I didn' t find anyone in my local supermarkets.
And I didn t want to buy any before to know if my Glow plug starter was out of order.
So I tried to print this Glow plug starter Tool who is to use on a 8mm plug ; my car is an Opel Corsa D .
I Used it and I was amazed because it worked on my all 4 Glow plugs .And more of that my 3d printed tool was not damaged at all and in pla .
I used an allen key (a 8mm one) to use it; but you can also use a 14 mm brench outside of the 3d printed tool.
If your plug has not the same size you can scale your design in your slicer.
Thank s to give your feed backe on it if you use it . And print it with 100% infill .
THX

J' ai créé cet outil parceque je n' ai pas trouvé d' outil dans les supermarchés auto dans les alentours de chez moi, et je ne voulais pas en achatté un sur internet avant de savoir si mes bougies d' allumage étaient HS.

description.text:
Do not print the download labbled "Chess set" It is strictly for show as there would be no colour differences and the peices would be stuck to the Board

This chess set with all its files may look daunting but by following the steps provided it will seem as easy as 1,2,3 and you’ll be able to show your new chess set to all your friends and family in no time.

  1. It’s easiest to start by first making the squares and then building out from there. You will notice that there are 3 different squares in your downloads. You will need:
    ->4 Corner Squares (2 of each colour)
    ->24 Side Squares (12 of each colour)
    ->36 Middle Squares (18 of each colour)

  2. Next we can move to the borders. You will have downloaded 2 different kinds of borders, left side border and right side border. Both of these will combine along their flat edge to form a border along one side of the chess board. Look at the picture of the completed chess set in the bio for more info. You will need to print:
    ->4 Right Side Borders
    ->4 Left Side Borders

  3. Now we have the most difficult part of the whole chess set, putting the board together. It will help to have an 18 by 18cm wood board to glue all these pieces to but it is not necessary.
    ->if you do have a board of wood you can start by glueing the Borders down first and then working outside in. Next you can add the corner squares in the corners so that their raised sides are agacent to the Borders. The side squares ligne the Sides of the board with their raised sides also touching the nearest border. Finally we have the middle squares which form the middle area of the board in a checker board fashion(refer to the picture in the bio for more information.)

  4. Finally you just have to print the chess pieces and clean them up and you’re ready to play a game of chess on your very own custom board.
    ->16 Pawns (8 of each colour)
    ->4 Rooks (2 of each colour)
    ->4 Knights (2 of each colour)
    ->4 Bishops (2 of each colour)
    ->2 Queens (1 of each colour)
    ->2 Kings (1 of each colour)

  5. HAVE FUN!!!!

Printer:

MonoPrice

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Notes:

-> Do not print the download labbled "Chess Set" It is strictly for show.

->If you don’t want to use the wood you may 3D print an alternative board or simply glue the pieces together without a board. Instead of glueing the pieces to the board you may glue them together instead. If you do so, note that it will be more fragile and more difficult to assemble.

->This chess set requirs 2 different colours of filament.

->The border should be in one of the colours you used for the chess set or simply a nice white or black.

title: Robocop ED-209 (Omni Consumer Products)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
There are quite a few ED-209s on the Internet for free but all of them have issues - either with accuracy or details or were just abandoned by their original publishers. I took the one on MyMiniFactory which I consider one of the best out there and fixed the visor so it is one piece with the upper head. The original model has an issue where the visor simply will not fit the printed head - irritating especially after a long 9 hr print job. There were many requests to fix it over the years - no answer - abandoned.

I fixed the visor merged to the head so it is one piece. I also fixed the gashes in the mesh (not sure why they were there) and also uploaded a lower poly count one. You can't see the difference but your slicer will. The fixed head without reducing poly count is 17MB, reduced poly is only about 5MB.

Print - Enjoy - Add and upate this model at your will. Do not sell it or try to make money off of it otherwise the original publisher will issue a DCMA takedown.

DO NOT PRINT THE LOW POLY COMPLETE ED-209. THIS IS ONLY FOR REFERENCE FOR ASSEMBLY.

UPDATE:

  • 2.24.18 - Added new head with NO support. Added complete head no support for SLA/DLP printing
  • Added updated Head Top and Low Poly - fixed a super minor .2mm gap.
  • Added split leg for easy printing

Original model: https://www.myminifactory.com/object/3d-print-ed209-from-robocop-5090

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Yes

.1mm

10% or less

Notes:

You can further split the legs, which I might do to minimize support scarring. You will need support for the back of the legs because they are long. I may provide a simplified leg without the rail vents (which look nice) but are a major PITA for FDM.

For SLS/DLP - go at it, this is a really awesome model!

title: Small wind turbine model
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: It is just small (lenght cca 500 mm) model of the wind turbine. It turns in a wind, but not as generator of the electricity. Just for fun and to see the wind direction and speed...

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Resolution:

0.1, 0.15, 0.2

Infill:

20-40%

Notes:

Parts with thread I used setup 0.1 mm layer, for other I used 0.2 mm. Blades I printed in 0.15.
I used PET-G at 240°C and 90° for bed.
To complete you need 1x M8 steel zinc plated rod and 4x small ball bearings 8x16x5 (628, 688).
Some fastenings too: 7x nuts M8 but narrow DIN439
and 3x screw M4x20 DIN912
Whole body is tighten by tread rod L=430 mm.
Then there is a small cut of M8 rod L-55mm in verical bearings. The rest of rod to 1m I used for vertical pole.
Because PET-G produce a lot of strings I printed all items one by one.
Some items are quite tall and slim, so I designed support myself. This support has large circle base and to model is connected by thin ribs, which is easy to cut by knife after printing.
Pure STL files, without this extra support are also included.
Just for fun and check it in wind...

description.text:
This is an experiment in using flexures to make a tensegrity structure out of printed parts. The zig-zag patterns in the tensile components makes them act like springs, putting load on the compression components and allowing the whole structure to flex.

To make your own, print out the following components:

  • 10x spring_03_short.STL
  • 5x stick_03_long.STL
  • 5x stick_03a.STL

Assemble using 10x McMaster Part #96817A908 thread forming screws (you'll need a T10 torx wrench). The assembly gets a little unwieldy once things are about 90% together and the flexures begin to get pulled into tension. I'd recommend assembling everything laid flat (connecting up all the tensile elements to the compression ones back-to-back as in the photo taken on the plywood backdrop) before connecting the first to the last member and forming a loop.

Leaving the screws backed out just a half turn and allowing some play on the connection will help the structure stay springy and prevent tangling as you assemble everything.

I've also made a little post about this design on my site here https://har.ms/blog/printed-tensegrity-toy

description.text:
This is my original idea to make unused shot glasses into volume measuring tools.

You can measure teaspoons (tsp), tablespoons (tbs), Ounces (oz), and milliliters (mL).

Just slide shot glass into the sleeve and measure desire volume. The height of the shot glass should be around 59mm and the outside diameter of the mouth should be around 50mm.

I designed the labels either protruding from the sleeve or as empty spaces in the sleeve or even 1mm recessed into the sleeve. Choose the one your printer is more comfortable with.

Absolutely not for commercial use, unless I get my cut :)

description.text: Air fresher for car / automobile vent. 2 grills need to be printed and 1 tray. I recommend starting with the tray with long clips as this is compatible with more vehicles. Fold a single piece of toilet paper folded into thirds twice and sandwitch it between the two grills. Insert the grills into the tray (I put the thicker edge of the grill down for strength.... and I point the slanted grill pieces toward the toilet paper so that drips roll in and not out. Put a few drops of essential oils or fragrance (Chocolate Mint :)) on the toilet paper and clip it on your car vent. Tray should be printed with support and the bottom side down.

author: mazhive

description.text:
I remixed my arduino boxes. And T70E’s gopro mounts.

My arduino boxes are a little more compact now. And the boxes all have open tops and bottoms. You will need 2 lids per box, one on the top and one on the bottom. And I included some gopro mounts for easy mounting. I searched for “Bolt Nut Screws for Gopro” on Ebay and bought some long thumb screws. They work great with this mount and box combination. If you don't want to use the gopro screws then an 8-32 X 3/4 works just as well. You'll need a screwdriver though. Better for an unseen, permanent mount.

In the pictures, the black prints and the white prints are PETG, the dark blue prints are PLA, and the light blue prints are ABS. When planning a project, I wouldn’t mix different filament prints the way I did in the pictures. That was for demonstration only. Keep PETG printed parts together. Keep ABS parts together. And keep PLA parts together. That way everything will fit together properly.

The boxes are 30mm X 60mm X 18mm tall. Placing a lid on the top and bottom brings it up to 20mm. Assembled, they are 30X60X20. There are 12 box and 8 lid options here in total.

I have 3 styles of single boxes, and 2 styles of double boxes WITH side cut outs for Nano access.
Single box, no gopro mount
Single box, single gopro mount (top)
Single box, double gopro mount (top and bottom)
Double box, single gopro mount (top)
Double box, double gopro mount (top and bottom)

I have 3 styles of single boxes, and 2 styles of double boxes WITHOUT side cut outs for Nano access.
Single box, no gopro mount
Single box, single gopro mount (top)
Single box, double gopro mount (top and bottom)
Double box, single gopro mount (top)
Double box, double gopro mount (top and bottom)

I made one more box. This one is 30 X 60 X 15mm tall with a 2mm closed bottom. No gopro mounts. This little box will hold one Nano (in the lid) and that’s about all that will fit. I made two of these, one with the nano access hole and one without. The box without is completely closed, so you will need to drill your own access holes for wiring.

There is a 3mm hole next to the nut side of each gopro mount, with a knockout for a 6mm hole. It makes a nicer looking finished project, but you have to wire in place. With the side cut outs you can pre-wire and drop in. Fast and easy or slower and better looking.

I had a problem with the double boxes letting go of the build plate mid print, so I added a small brim running down the middle to help with bed adhesion. Trim away post print.

I have 8 different lids.
A – Arduino Nano – or Arduino Pro Mini. There is a stop at the back and an indent in the front. You have to push past the indent, then it will lock the Nano into place. The Pro Mini will slide around a little. Solder your wires first, angle them inboard a little bit, then slide it in.

HC-SR04 – This lid will hold one HC-SR04 ultrasonic sensor. The 2 holes might be a little tight and need to be sanded slightly. This is the reason I designed these boxes with an open back side. I can mount an HC-SR04 in the front, and an Arduino Nano (or Pro Mini) in the back lid. Both will fit into a single box. You will have to fold over the 4 pins on the HC-SR04. And I threw a small piece of electrical tape in there to make sure they keep separated. It does get a little tight after wiring, but still very do-able.

Relay – These boxes are too small for the relay module boards, but, 2 tiny blue relays will fit just fine.
OR – one relay and one screw terminal. Stop laughing at my solder job – it was late.
You will need 2 relay lids, one for the top and one for the bottom. They sandwich the relays into position. I used the arduino relay schematic here: http://www.instructables.com/id/Arduino-Relay-Circuit/ - minus the indicating LED.

PIR – This lid will hold one PIR unit, and nothing else will fit into the box. You will need a couple of drops of super glue on the 2 pins. This helps with the rigidity of this lid because it is pretty thin and weak on the edges of the circle cut out. I enlarged the circle cut out slightly, from my arduino boxes, so I (we) don’t have to fight it anymore.

LM-2596 – This lid will hold one LM-2596 DC-DC voltage converter, and nothing else will fit into the box.

1 LED – (1) 5mm hole for an LED

2 LED’s – (2) 5mm holes for LED’s

Blank – just a blank cover

Here is a file list and descriptions:
1b 0gp oh 1 bay, 0 gopro mounts, 0 nano access holes
1b 0gp 2h 1 bay, 0 gopro mounts, 2 nano access holes
1b 1gp oh 1 bay, 1 gopro mounts, 0 nano access holes
1b 1gp 2h 1 bay, 1 gopro mounts, 2 nano access holes
1b 2gp oh 1 bay, 2 gopro mounts, 0 nano access holes
1b 2gp 2h 1 bay, 2 gopro mounts, 2 nano access holes
2b 1gp oh 2 bays, 1 gopro mounts, 0 nano access holes
2b 1gp 2h 2 bays, 1 gopro mounts, 2 nano access holes
2b 2gp oh 2 bays, 2 gopro mounts, 0 nano access holes
2b 2gp 2h 2 bays, 2 gopro mounts, 2 nano access holes

These two boxes are 15mm tall with a 2mm bottom. This will hold 1 Nano or 1 Pro Mini
1b 15mm 0gp oh 1 bay, 0 gopro mounts, 0 nano access holes
1b 15mm 0gp 2h 1 bay, 0 gopro mounts, 2 nano access holes

The lids:
lid 1led (1) 5mm LED
lid 2leds (2) 5mm LED’s
lid a Arduino Nano or Pro Mini
lid b Blank
lid hc-sr04 HC-SR04
lid lm2596 LM2596
lid pir PIR
lid r Relay(s)

I slightly remixed the gopro mounts. The originals fit very tight even without the screw, and I was concerned about breaking boxes. I made all the slots 3mm wide and everything fits well now.

Depending on your print setup, the lids might fit slightly loose into the boxes. I have some that fit tight and some that slide out. You can heat up the legs and spread them out a little bit. Or once you are all done with your project you can just glue the lid onto the box.

Notes:

I have printed these in ABS, PLA, and PETG

ABS 225 nozzle 100 bed .2 layer 100% infill
PLA 215 nozzle 60 bed .2 layer 100% infill
PETG 235 nozzle 70 bed .2 layer 100% infill

Done with Tinkercad simple badge with name. As a base sample was taken fish pattern.
Printed with 0,15 layer height, 23% infill, 0,4 nozzle size

Welcome to my Filament Scale project. I have had this mounted to my Taz5 for over a year
and have been quite happy with its operation and accuracy. There will be some error because of the pulling of the filament but it gives me a good idea of how much filament I have before starting a project. I've included a wall mount or it could be used as an adapter for a different printer.

The parts were printed out of ABS at 25 percent fill. Nothing special but you need to be able to print accurately to receive the 608zz bearings with no problems. The support arm rotates on the bearings to contact the 3kg load cell mounted vertically.

The electronics would be the hardest part and you need to have a little experience to get that done. It uses a ESP32 Dev board displaying on a Nextion NX3224T028-011 display. Power comes from the micro usb cable plugged into your computer or from an adapter. You need to follow Andreas Spiess #170 youtube video to get Arduino to compile the code properly. I've included the source code for the ESP32 and the display. The HMI file for the display uses no special graphics so it should work with any T version display. I guess this is an advanced project so if you don't understand what I'm referring to then this probably isn't a good project for you at this time.

I hope someone would run with this and add the HX711 load cell sensor to the Octoprint project and add this scale. Hope to do that when time permits, I currently don't use Octoprint so I only assume it's possible to do so, heck maybe it does.

It operates like any digital scale. You tare or zero it out with an empty spool to show you the remaining filament. The first time you run it you will need to go hit the CAL button and adjust the gain to read correctly with a known weight applied.

Sorry for not a more detailed build but I've got more projects to attend to.

Cheers

title: E3D Cyclops Mount for MP Select Mini

description.text:
I created a mount for an E3D cyclops nozzle to fit on my MP Select Mini. This mount was designed using a Cylops clone I purchased on eBay but the holes should line up.

The first part attaches to the X-axis carriage. simply take the old nozzle off and remove the 2 bolts located behind the X-axis belt. I was able to mount my plate with the carriage and belt still intact.

The second part is a shim to push the nozzle forward to be slightly more in line with the original nozzle. The part also acts a cover to sandwich the small nuts from the original mount in between. While my original parts were mounted just using the grip the plastic, I found that pressing the 2 nuts into the plate made the mount a great deal stronger and resistant to coming loose.

When making the part be sure to use a material suited to the heat of the heatsink. I chose to print in HIPS and ABS. I have yet to try PET or PETG as they may also be suitable.

title: "Mouse" Ears Hat Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A non destructive hat mount for DIY mouse ears!

I wanted to make a way to attach ears to a hat, but not ruin the hat. I found wrap around earmuffs from the dollar store ($1.25) looked perfect for mouse ears.

Build steps:
-Cut ears in half
-Trim to just rounded part
-Print mount
-Sew ears to outer mount, using the small holes at the base of the large flap.
-Put internal mount in and pop pin through hat hole
-Put external mount (with ear stitched on) onto pin registration.
-Stitch the inner and outer together using the mini holes on end of arms. (holes to holes)
-Enjoy!!!

Updated to v2 with better stability.

comments.text: My initial cover was fully printed https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1623399 but eventually the area, where the hot air was flowing, started to deform and crack. That's why I decided to use mesh. However, the big difference is - in my case the cover was printed as a single piece and this opening was part of a vertical wall. When printed flat it will be much stronger, so your design should work. Just make sure to print with PETG or ABS. From my experience PLA proved to be bad choice when constantly exposed to even such an insignificant amount of heat.

author: Kawadarze

description.text:
I believe it is always cleaner to be able to disconnect various electrical components quickly without tools. Low cost, high current connectors for low Voltage DC have been few and far between until several years ago when the industry introduced a quick disconnect connector designed for connecting high power stereo speakers like are used at concerts. These connectors are rated at 30 Amps and have 4 contacts, 2 labeled “+” and 2 labled “-”, which makes it ideal for connecting the power cable between the power supply and the motherboard (2 wires) and the bed heater mosfet switch (2 wires). The mosfet switch (Little Driver) I use is mounted in the housing pictured next to the power connector and is made by Digital Sqrt.

These connectors are available from Digi-Key, Parts Express, Amazon, etc. in the US or slightly cheaper (< $2.50 USD per pair) from AliExpress in China.

I have designed a housing to mount the bulkhead to the “2020” extruded rail base used on all Kossel delta printers along with a trim piece which hides the wires. The connector is secured to the housing with #2 X 3/8” sheet metal screws and the housing is connected to the base extrusions with M4 x 10 screws and M4 hammer T nuts.

title: Improved Fidget Spinner Caps
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Here is a slight improvement over some of the caps I've seen available. I added a small ridge where the bearing hub hits preventing the caps from rubbing on the bearing seals or outer ring. There are two types, one with a concave center and one that is flat. The concave cap didn't print well with PETG because I could not get the supports out. Other material will be better in that regard. I also include 3 plugs for outer bearings that you may used in the spinner. They also work great as cooling towers and help improve the overall accuracy of the caps.

author: alfeuchtwa

title: JG Aurora A3 Radial Dial Mount

description.text:
This mounts to the back of the print carriage so you can manually tram the print bed in reference to the carriage. I used a layer of duct tape (because Red/Green) to take up the space I left to allow it to slide on and off. This is only installed during a manual tram because it will interfere with all automatic operations.

It was interesting to see how much variation I had in the stock print bed and will be upgrading to glass to help improve consistency. I'm using an inexpensive dial for this application since this initially just started out as an experiment. I also use Octopi to control the manual motion so that my pushing does not influence the measure.

I hope others find this useful.

Enjoy.

title: Bottom and legs for Jacobsen Egg chair by Deleven

description.text: Bottom and legs for the Jacobsen Egg chair by Deleven. I have made the bottom for the chair to make it round and not flat. I also added legs that look closer to the original with feet. The original center column of the legs are thinner. I designed an endstop for the center column. This way when the bottom with the legs is glued to the chair, the legs does not fall off and the chair can turn.

Printer:

Creality CR-10S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Printed legs and endstop with 0.4 nozzle and 0.1 mm layer height and 10% infill.
Print 4 copies of the feet.
The feet are printed with same settings but 100% infill.

How to assemble

First print the chair by Deleven and my parts.
Glue the feet to the legs
Stick the feet center column trough the bottom part and glue the endstop to the center column. Make sure the legs can turn freely. You might need to use sand paper either in the hole or on the center column if it is a tight fit.
When the glue has dried, glue the bottom to the chair, and the model is done.

title: Ada Robotic Hand - Logoless Left Dorsal Hand Cover

description.text:
Thank you to Open Bionics for providing this project; I feel that it is important to allow commercial use as a means to create incentives for people to work and spend their own money to build these devices. Creating one of these hands comes with a $50-$80 per actuator cost x 5; So to scratch build one of these will be $500 or more + Circuit Fab / contract the circuitry + Batteries +Labor, etc... To be able to build these and offer them for sale offers many advantages over prohibition of commercial use. (Why would someone sink half a grand into a device that then becomes worthless for resale? I think the average person is motivated by compensation for their work and investments, so Open Bionics is spot on allowing commercialization of this device.) Plus, if the market value is $XX, then if folks were to donate them as some other "Open Source" projects suggest as the only mode, they'd know how to quantify that donation for their taxes for charity.
Open Bionics provided the Blender files, which I used to remove the overly prominent "back of the hand" Open Bionics label. If someone needed to use a glove, or otherwise found that the logo was tooo obtrusive, you can use this dorsal cover instead.
Also, I believe that an exception to medical device law should classify this as a garment / clothing, rather than as a medical device. As long as it's worn like a glove there should be no prohibitions as a "medical device", but instead as a "mechanical glove"... These regulations are stifling wider implementation of these devices.

title: TRONXY X5S Z AXIS SINGLE STEPPER CONVERSION

description.text:
As everyone who owns an X5S the Z Axis can be an issue.
This modification allows one stepper to drive both linear shafts. Doing this will eliminate the issue of the print bed out of calibration due to stepper motor missing steps.
It will not totally eliminate the issue, but if the single stepper motor misses a step at least it's across both linear shafts.
I have added the SKP files in case slight adjustments are needed for your printer setup.

Printer:

Tronxy X5S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 or 0.2

Infill:

50% Plus

Notes:

You must think about the supports you use as when supports are generated the software can creat supports that block the nut holes on parts.

Extra parts needed

6 X pillow block bearings with 8mm bore on bearing.
2 x smooth pulleys
3 GT2 Pulleys that lock to the shaft 1 x 5mm bore 2 x 8mm bore
closed loop belt 1140mm was for my printer you will have to calculate this.
8mm threaded rod
8mm smooth rod to make the stepper shafts
8mm to 8mm couplers.
m5 16 bolts and T-nuts for the feet
A selection of m3 nuts and bolts
M4 bolts and T nuts for adjuster

The stepper frame is based on a v slide.
The assembly has been made to screw down on an 18mm baseboard that sits on the angle brackets shown in a photo. You will have to cut a rectangle hole in the board to accommodate the mount, but make sure that allowance is made for the mount to rest ontop of the board and to screw it down.
The positioning of the frame is critical for correct operation to ensure the belt does not foul with it's self. You only need a slight gap between the belt but bear this in mind when marking the board out.
As you might have to mod these parts I have added the sketchup files.
the feet were created as a remake from
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2477288

remixed_from.author: mrappz
remixed_from.title: Z axis endstop clicker for Anet E-10

title: Anet E10 Z endstop adjuster / X switch holder

description.text:
I used MrCrankyface's Z endstop switch holder, then tried a handful of endstop adjusters. All were problematic for various reasons- they didn't line up with the Z endstop switch, the X switch was in the wrong place to contact the carriage, the bracket interfered with the X belt or zipties, and so on.

So I iterated, eventually printing over 20 versions of my design. It uses M2 bolts (12-16mm) and nuts to hold the switch, will take a M3 hammer nut, and is designed for a M3 Z adjuster bolt. You will probably need to ream the adjuster hole a bit, which is what I prefer when "threading" a bolt directly against plastic. You can ream it for a M4 if you want.

The design has a hollow cube to the side; this lets the extruder head alternate between printing the cube and printing the adjuster. When the extruder gets to the 'foot' of the adjuster, the tallest part while on the print bed, it has a tendency to overheat and turn the foot into a blob. This does a great job of preventing that.

I designed it in Thingiverse, you can ungroup/move/regroup all of the parts if you need it to fit differently. https://www.tinkercad.com/things/icLLEqRz4G3

Note CC-BY-NC; this is not to be used for (re)sale.

author: Dom_e

description.text:
Gloomhaven character tray, designed for 2nd edition.

Accommodates ability, attack modifier and item cards in separate dividers, plus class tokens and the miniature (for most classes). For storage, the health/xp dial, character sheet and character mat/card are placed on top.

Bottom left character token area is ramped to make it easier to slide tokens out.

Can optionally be used during play as well (see pictures).

Character mat held in by pinching the bottom of the cardboard, so the flex of the plastic is used to pinch the card and hold it in place. You should have to flex the tray slightly to get the card to fall into place.

Stacking 4 of these trays comes out to be the same height as the class tuck boxes in the original game box.

Files / Versions:

  • v9 - First released model. Accepts sleeved small cards, but not large cards.
  • v10 - Resized dividers to fit sleeved cards. Reduced size of compartment to hold mini. See "card sleeves" notes below. Holes added to bottom of tray to reduce print time and plastic use.

Card sleeves:

Update:

The v9 model will fit small cards using Fantasy Flight "mini euro" (red) sleeves. Large ability cards will not fit if sleeved.

The v10 model is now sized to fit sleeved cards, however it is only tested with Fantasy Flight red (mini euro) and clear (standard card) sized sleeves. The fit is very tight like within a fraction of a millimeter, so your printer will need to be well tuned for your final print to work correctly. Sleeves that are larger than the FF sleeves will likely not work. I had to reduce the size of the compartment that holds player tokens and the mini, so some of the larger minis might not fit now, but most still should (I haven't unlocked every character to try them all)

Printing notes:

You will need a fairly large print bed to fit this. It is a hair wider than a character card, so you can use one of those to judge if your print bed is big enough.

Also the character mat is held in place by "pinching" the bottom of the card (see photos). This means the flex in the plastic is used to bend and open up the tray to get the character mat into it. Because of this, your printer needs to be very accurate. Please make sure your printer's X and Y distance are calibrated properly.

title: Nutball motor mount flight test pattern

description.text:
Hi,
take a look at my other designs https://www.thingiverse.com/mg_evolution/designs

The test piece goes into the foam board body to see if the print will fit your application

I have made a Nutball based on the flight test online plans.
I made a Brushless motor mount for the swappable body that will allow my 20amp ESC through it and space to mount a LED at the front bottom.

FT Swappable brushless Motor Mount Round.stl is a single print to allow better airflow to the body of the plane.

I used 5mm foam board and have based the sizes around this.
The hole size is 45mm wide x 31mm high,
There is a lip at the top to secure the nutball to the motor mount.
The smaller prints are guides for holes in the foam board, this will allow fixing the parts together with 2 x M3 screw and nut.

The screw head supports for the foam can be found here from my Skyhunter design:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2748008

If anyone has another hole size required and different size foam I can adjust this and post it up on request.

description.text:
"You know me I'm Reverse Giraffe.
I have a short neck and legs."

Four colors - black, white, yellow and brown.

Four pieces - two eyes, one body, one outline.

This assembles in a similar fashion to Best President Ever. The Outline has to be the last piece printed.

Eyes - white, 0.2 mm layers.

Body - yellow, change to brown at 1.1 mm. 0.1 mm layers.

Outline - black,0.1 mm layers, pause at 2.1 mm. Do not remove Outline from the print bed! Put the Body and Eye pieces in the Outline. Make sure the pieces are flat in the Outline. Use superglue to secure them. Make sure the extruder is primed and resume printing, the final layers will draw details on the Body and seal the edges. Z hop will help reduce any gouging.

Print out the super cool stand, or attach a strip of magnet to his back and hang him on the fridge!

author: Pottok

description.text:
If you want easy access to the belly of the printer, have it a bit higher so you can mount a quiet fan on the power supply and make the printer more stable.

This does not make the printer silent. It does however in theory make it print better if you stick the bottom part to a concrete paver because it won't move as much during resonances.
See this excellent video: https://youtu.be/OnfYA5QLA84

The feet will make the printer clear 20mm +1mm for the holder.

I recommend screwing the feet with the original screws as in the image. This fit exactley on my i3 Mega w. Ultrabase. 8bit Trigorilla.

You need to print 2 of each.

You can use only the feet without the holder and stick some felt pads under them or use doublesided tape to stick the holders into place and stick your printer down for more stability.

title: Walmart ReliOn Humidifier Filter Bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: The generic replacement filters I bought for this humidifier don't have the metal grid down the middle that the originals did, so they gradually move out of position and more air flows around them than through. This design eliminates that issue, although it does make it more difficult to replace the filter as well. At the very least, the humidifier now seems to be emptying its reservoir more quickly with the fan set to low than it used to do set to high. Setting it to high just seems to make the motor struggle and not result in any additional airflow since it is now limited by how much air it can pull through the filter. I expect it would help if I replace or at least demineralize the filter, but I'm kind of busy designing parts for other household items around here. ;-)

author: hexvenn

title: Paintball BT Flip Switch Safety Conversion (No Modifcation Needed!)

description.text:
This is a conversion for BT (Battle Tested) Paintball markers to remove the original push button safety, and replace it with a flipping lever safety. The reason for this new safety is to remove the chance of accidently turning the safety off when setting down your marker, and vice versa when in battle. Since these pieces need to be neat and exact, I printed my pieces at 20mm a second. And since the main piece doesn't have that much surface contact on the bed while printing, I recommend using some glue from a glue stick on the bed. Supports are obviously required on the first piece. Some sanding may be required.

How to Install:

Steps also shown in photos!

  1. Take off the pistol grip from your BT marker.

  2. Pull out the old push safety from the left side.

  3. Take out the trigger Mechanism.

  4. On the same side, place the 180 degree stop piece (2nd Piece) on top of the hole from the inside. (The cut off corner facing forward)

  5. While holding the stop piece (Second Piece) in place, slide just the end of the other piece in so it doesn't actually go through, but the end of it is flush with the stop piece's top. Note that the lever (1st Piece) must stay on the top 180 degrees otherwise it will not go through because that's how it keeps it turning only 180 degrees. This may be tricky.

  6. Wiggle the trigger mechanism back into place.

  7. Slide the lever (1st Piece) the rest of the way though the trigger mechanism.

  8. Reassemble your marker.

Please let me know if you have any questions!

author: ryanjgill

title: Unicorn - An ESP8266 thermometer and humidity meter

description.text:
Unicorn is an ESP8266 based high precision wireless thermometer and humidity meter. To achieve high accuracy, the sensor used is the SHT21. Once measured, the device uploads the data to variables hosted on VariPass. The whole device is designed to run off a single 18650 Li-Ion battery, and can potentially keep running for a month thanks to ESP's deep sleep functionality (Not yet tested however!).

Features

  • Measures temperature and humidity using an SHT21 sensor.
  • Measures battery status as percentage or voltage.
  • Can connect to up to 8 different WiFi networks and switch between them.
  • Uploads data to VariPass.
  • A status LED indicates the success of the upload process when enabled.
  • Runs off a single 18650 Li-Ion battery.
  • Supports ESP's deep sleep feature for prolonged battery life.
  • Lots of configuration available in the software.
  • Features a slot on the back which fits an M5 countersunk screw, used for hanging on a wall.
  • USB port is exposed for charging and programming.
  • Case designed in such a way to minimize heat transfer.
  • A small hole on the back used to reset the board using a paper clip.

Required Hardware

  • Croduino NOVA
  • SHT21 Breakout
  • Holder for 18650 Li-Ion Battery
  • 18650 Li-Ion Battery - Can be a different one than linked here as well.
  • Battery protection circuit - You might need top find a listing which offers them individually. Datasheet: link
  • A slide switch similar to this one. A different one will probably not work. You will need to change the design a bit if you wish to use a different one.
  • Some cables for wiring
  • 8x M3*16 countersunk screws
  • 1x M3*10 countersunk screw
  • 1x M3 nut

Required Software
Unicorn runs software written by myself, It is available on my GitHub.

Printing & Assembly
Print everything without any supports and exactly as already oriented for best results.

Assembly is pretty straight forward and with the correct hardware, everything snaps into place. Picture 3 shows the general layout and assembly of all the printed parts and hardware. Four M3*16 screws hold the upper parts in place, and four hold the lower. One M3*10 screw along with an inserted nut into the Unicorn_Sensor.stl holds the side cover.

You will need to do a lot of soldering to wire everything up. Please check pictures 4, 5 and 6 on this upload and pay attention to the cable colors.

As always, I am providing the .blend file as well in case you wish to modify this.

This HPL (hand powered light) uses a cheap AliExpress geared DC motor. It supplies enough energy for a 100 mA led (white, 10mm). The basic circuit has a resistor and led, that's all you need to make light.
A 1000uF capacitor can be added to stabilize the light flow. The diode prevents dischargeing through the motor. Depending on left or right handed use: No light? Reverse the motor wires.
In case you want to make it independent of the rotation direction, a bridge rectifier can be added.
It all fits in a handy housing that is closed bij a lid. The grip rotates around an M4 bolt.

comments.text: Looks good, can the crank be rotated in either direction? If not, would it be good to embed a graphic showing the direction of rotation? I have some 3,000 uF 6V capacitors, do you think it would be safe to use one? I fear that when the voltage goes over 6V, it could blow the capacitor.
comments.author: CaptObvious

comments.text: I measured 4 volts. The value on capacitors have a large safely margin. So, use it. The crank has one active direction. You can change it by reversing the motor wires, or use the lower circuit on the picture.

description.text:
Moving from Blender to OpenSCAD as a design tool. Scaling the stake in OpenSCAD is much better since you have direct control over each dimension - for my printer, setting the thickness to 1.9mm was ideal (avoiding tiny gaps of hex-fill), in Blender I didn't have a good way to scale the thickness and other stake dimensions independently.

Most of the original Wire Stakes (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1777967) worked fine, but occasionally one would crack when being hammered into a tree root - this iteration puts a little thickening in the areas that were breaking first in the older design.

In my soil, the 150mm stakes are usually long enough, but when the sand is really soft and dry, longer is better. 240mm is about as long as I can fit on my print bed (it has to be turned at an angle.) The 150mm stake takes about 3.2m of filament to print, or ~$0.20 worth, $10 for a box of 50, if you don't count your machine time.

Intended to be placed under an M570 mouse in order to help keep it still on the desk. In my case lasercut from project foam. DXF file.

3D print a forest of unique, customized trees using Thingiverse Customizer. With about a dozen parameters, the Customizable Tree allows you to easily generate all the flora your inner arborist desires. We just upgraded Customizer to a more recent version of OpenSCAD (2013.06), so we created the Customizable Tree to show off some of the new features. It now supports recursion, or the process of repeating similar shapes, in modules and functions and the scaling parameter for linear extrusions which allows the tree branches to taper. Additionally, the tree customizer uses a new library we wrote for handling 3D vectors and a small library for converting hue-saturation-value colors to RGB. The 3D vector library comes with some helpful functions for rotating vectors toward other vectors as well as a module for visualizing vector paths. *[Edit [3/28/14]:
  • Updated the branches to used a simplified version of custom shapes to fix very long render times.
  • Fixed a bug where the branch caps weren't rotating properly with twisted branches.
  • Added a new "Advanced Settings" tab to expose some of the more finicky parameters. Please note, the advanced settings can produce unprintable geometry!*

By default, these will not have extreme overhangs and thus won't need supports. You can turn off that feature with the "Allow All Overhangs" option in Customizer. We've gotten great prints with standard slice settings (.2 mm layer height and 2 shells).  
Let us know what kinds of settings you use to print them!

comments.text: The randomizing code has a bug (or maybe this is expected?); the same seed value is used for every single branch at all levels, which means that only a single random value is used for each varying parameter, e.g. all branches will have 3 sub-branches, even if you set the range from 2-5.  I fixed this locally by having a global counter which I incremented in each call to the branch creator.  I added this value to the seed in every rands() call, so that a unique seed is used for each branch.  this makes the trees a lot more random and realistic.

print_settings.Notes:: A food safe material like PLA would probably be a good idea.

description.text:
When you rinse out your growler there's still a fair amount of water left in it and upright it takes forever to dry. Turn it upside down and mine are unwieldy, likely to fall over and break as soon as the family pet walks past.

To get around this I made a stand so it sits stable. All the water will drain out in about an hour. After that turn it upright, leave it open and it'll dry completely overnight, ready for the next fill.

If you have a smaller growler like the second picture just scale the geometry to the size of the opening before printing and it should work just as well. The original is 40mm which fits the 45-46mm inside diameter growlers I have. Leaving a couple five mm of slop so the fit isn't too tight is recommended.

Notes:

A food safe material like PLA would probably be a good idea.

print_settings.Notes:: Print Cover Slip out of clear filament

description.text:
3D Printer Host is a do it yourself electronic device created with a wifi enabled Adafruit Feather, a Neopixel ring, and a 3D printed enclosure. The device connects to OctoPrint via its API and the wonderful OctoPrint API library for Arduino. It displays the prints progress as well as state on the Neopixel ring. The 3D Printer Host also connects to Alexa via Thingspeak and a custom skill which allows a user to ask Alexa about many aspects of their printer and find details about any current print. More information about this device can be found here:
https://www.hackster.io/Milesnash_/3d-printer-monitoring-with-alexa-and-arduino-024292

There are three options for printing the enclosure. First, you can print the 'Base', 'Outer Cover', and 'Inner Cover' in a color of your choice and print the 'Cover Slip' out of a transparent filament. The three cover parts will snap together causing the Neopixel ring to shine directly through the transparent filament. Second, the 'Base', 'Outer Cover', and 'Inner Cover' can be printed out of a color of your choice allowing the raw Neopixels to be seen. The third option is to print the 'Full Cover' along with the 'Base' in a lighter color filament and let the light shine through the single color of the cover.

author: jjporter13

description.text:
These cubes are perfect to check stringinging (and multiple check for other tests).
There is a bottom layer connecting the cubes so you can mark and keep them.

I normally check with new filaments by default:

  • slicing with 0.2mm, 2 perimeters, 1-3 bottom layers, no top layer and no infill.
  • choose a reasonable speed (50mm/s) (modify later by GCode M220 S)
  • "normal" temperatures for bed and hot end (modify during print to check for influence of temp)
  • travel speed to 200mm/s
  • retraction 5mm, 60mm/s (550mm bowden to e3d)

The boxes are 20mm, and distance 10, 20 and 40mm between each.
After temperature sweet spot is found, one can play with travel speed and retraction.

author: alanhinchcliffe

description.text:
I have been using this site for ideas and occasional projects that are provided and I wanted to give back to this site and it's contributors with this model.
The Star Spool is designed to be used in conjunction with the mounting panel provided on the project page titled "Dremel Idea Builder Filament Spool" submitted by user "justjerms1971".
I downloaded his/her project file to use in its original form some time ago. It worked as an exterior spool holder and did so with only a little tweaking to get pieces to fit as expected - it's a fine project and well worth using.

That said - I found that it did not allow for filament de-spooling when I mounted standard 2.2K rolls on it. After trying other add-on fixes (without luck) to eliminate this issue I finally decided to design my own spool holder that would eliminate the need for these other fixes to make the original spool holder work as I needed.

The Star Spool has worked flawlessly since I started using it and keeps the filament where it needs to be with little to no additional drag on the rotating filament spool when being drawn by the printer. It fits with any standard 2.2K spool with a 58mm hub diameter.
The Star Spool uses three arms that press fit into the extensions of the star. These friction fit points are modestly adjustable to allow how close one wants the arms to be to the spool outer circumference. I suggest setting them as close as possible without added drag being placed on the spool edge but with the closeness necessary to keep the filament from inadvertently slipping under an arm and then de-spooling or binding.

title: Anet A2 parts cooler / rear mount blower

description.text:
A parts cooler bracket / holder for the Anet A2.

Spec -
Rear mount (so it doesn't obstruct view of print and looks better).
Blower 50x50x15 (http://a.co/6omY7mc) (higher CFM vs 40x40x10 fan).
Easy to install (use existing mounting bolt locations).
Wide air path distribution (I read parts prints better vs narrow nozzle).
Easily adjustable for Y and Z positions.
Simple to print (without needs of support).

Prep -
The two rear M5 bolts on the X platform needed to be lengthened to provide for bracket mounting.

While I was at this, I insulated the heating block with these 2mm tick Heating Block Cotton sheets.
http://a.co/cQbpCRB

Design oversight -
I ended up not using screws to mount the blower, tolerance was too tight. The screw head ended up getting too close to the bed on the blower under side and the other end of the screw too close to the under side of the X gantry, and the screw length had to be specially sized. None of these were good options. I ended up using hot glue and works great. There are now about 5mm of gap between lowest part of blower to the print bed.

Design concerns -
The blower air in-take is on the under side, not sure if this could pickup loose filaments and gets sucked into the fan fouling it and the print.

author: jcmygod

description.text:
I really liked @raveious' "Interior Webcam Mount" -- a rail and camera mount designed for the Makerbot Replicator 2 and the Logitech C270 webcam -- but wanted to adapt to be used on other printers. What I ended up doing is making a few different kinds of camera mounts off of the original design.

This version is made to be mounted on an exterior corner. I recently built an Ikea LACK table enclosure and wanted to mount a webcam inside of the enclosure, attached to the table leg.

The rail, peg back and the forked camera mount are from "Interior Webcam Mount" -- everything is part of the camera mount system. Also, the only hardware needed are M3 nuts and bolts.

To get started, you'll need to print a rail, a peg back and two rail mounts. Next, select the type of camera mount you want:

  1. Flush snap -- Peg is a snap which fits into the snap mount
  2. Ball and Socket -- Peg is a socket which is made for the ball mount
  3. Screw Ball with stem -- Peg is a ball cup with a tightening lid for the screw ball stem which snaps into the screw ball snap mount

Once you've printed the additional parts for your chosen mount system, put it all together.

My favorite mount is the "screw ball" because it has the best range of motion so that you can point the camera exactly where you want.

Note: The ball and socket joint works, but I've found that it can be tricky to print and, depending on your printer's tolerances, you might need to do some sanding to get the ball to fit in the socket.

Just practicing/learning to make lithophanes. Very cool.

Update: I've since learned that printing Lithophanes on their EDGE, vertically, is far far superior. The quality is so much better, that I no longer switch to my 0.25 nozzle, nor .04 layer thickness. I get fantastic lithophanes from my 0.4 nozzle and printing at 0.1 thickness. But, larger is better. Small details, esp dark ones, like EYES are still a challenge. My current lithophanes are usually 80x80. I got the vertical idea from www.thingiverse.com/thing:2718124.

  • Fix your fence!

I needed a small swivel base to position a small camera. I figured I'd go for broke and cover all the bases with a variety of components.

These are a snug fit and the rougher finish that comes with a .2mm layer height gives them good gription (i think that's a word).

SooOOoo ... . .I realized that the PLA female ends were relaxing over time and losing their ever critical gription. So, I added a groove for an O-ring. This probably isn't necessary for some materials. I'm still pretty new at this and, so far I've only used PLA. And, obviously, I'm still learning about that. Anyway, there are now grooved and groove free versions.

These won't keep your go pro in position while you jump your BMX into a lake but they will keep your phone pointed at the table while you Instagram yourself cutting tomatoes. Honestly don't know why that's a thing but you do you.

title: Adapter to convert ups to emergency light controller

description.text:
This filler is part of converting a small APC UPS to operate power-outage lights (elights) it fits two panel-mount dc jacks that can be used to plug in low power 12V led lights.

hey, you kill yourself its your fault ok?
danger high voltage

NO, IT WONT WORK AS A UPS AFTER THIS.

step 1) turn ups off (duh)
step 2) unplug UPS (duh)

step A (seperate thread, you can have your buddy doing this while you continue with the numbered steps) ) Start printing the thing that came with these instructions.

step 3) flip over, open battery compartment, remove battery.
step 4) remove the 4 screws that hold on the top lid, remove lid.

-- this is white space for people who dont or cant read large blocks of text --

step 5) there are 6 screws on the top of the circuit board that hold it down, remove those.

step B ) remove the 2 screws in the back of the case that hold on the output outlet.

step 6) remove the 5 wires to the transformer. (step 5.5 is to google everything about electronics so you know how to follow these instructions, including knowing what a transformer is).

step 7) watch tv for a while (this step is optional)

step C) remove the black and white wires from the output outlet.

step 8) gently move the circuit board aside, there is one screw holding the back of the transformer, remove it.

step 9) wiggle and pull the transformer back, its got its front tab trapped under the battery door brace, will usually pull out. Ditch it.

step D) solder 20cm wires to the dc jacks, 16 guage is a good minimum, red to the centre post and black to the outter cylinder.

step 10) unsolder the wires that went to the outlet from the circuit board, optionally, you can also just cut them off really close to the circuit board.

step E) crimp push-on connectors to the wires, each black wire gets its own crimp connector, but both red wires go into the same connector.

step 11) screw the dc connectors into the printed peice, their tight but use the nut anyhow.

step 12) wait for the other guy.

step F) go get some potato chips (optional step)

step 13) unsolder the 40A fuse and replace it with something like a 5A or 10A fuse. (usually a computer power supply has a 6.3A fuse that I'm sure you can make fit if you try.)

step G) screw the dc jack plate back into the back of the case (from the inside), you will need 2x 6-32 screws, you can steal 2 of 4 screws holding in the power supply of the other guys computer, cause why does it need 4 screws for anyhow????

step 14) plug in the dc connectors. There is one connection by the fuse you just replaced, the red wires go to that one. Each of the black wires (he used black right!?) goes to the connectors by each set of transistors.

step 15) screw the circuit board back into the case.

step 16) eat potato chips, wait for the other guy to finish. Keep an eye on him, he might be trying to steal screws out of your computer.

step H) unsolder that tiny, stupid, annoying little buzzer from the circuit board, you can also use the 'removed-with-large-pliers' technique.

step G) solder-blob-jumper-togethor pins 13-14 of IC7 (should be a 3524) also blob togethor pins 11-12. (this step locks on the fets when the power goes out) remember when counting pins that the chip is upside down, doublecheck the pin numbers.

step 17) wait for other guy to finish, eat potato chips.

step 18) screw the case lid back on

step 19) reinstall battery.

step I) solder a male dc jack onto some led lights. positive is center.

step 20) eat potato chips. wait for other guy.

step 21) plug in led lights.

step J) eat potato chips. (this is threading at its best)

step 22) turn on UPS

step 23) plug in UPS briefly, then unplug, lights should come on.

step 23.5) go to thingverse and click the 'I made one'! thing number 2798705

step 24) plug ups in, wait for power outage.

description.text:
This holder allows to install some twigs at the ceiling around a standard lamp socket. I designed them to function as an extensive base for a mobile.

The parts have been modeled in OpenSCAD and are fully configurable. All measures one might want to alter, reside in Dimensions.scad and are fully documented. If you find anything unclear, just let me know.

The included stl files are based on a configuration for at least six arms (I only used five of the in my photos) a screw distance of 60 mm (which, I think, is a standard in Europe) and standard device screws (also shown in the pictures). The screw holes are a tight fit in this configuration, but I didn't want to sacrifice any stability.

I included my curasettings and the resulting gcode files for informational purposes only. Don't use them for direct printing unless your're pretty sure you know what you're doing.

As always: caution has to be taken when working with electricity and you should seriously know what you're doing! Make sure the lamp below the holder doesn't get too hot or too close to other parts, that might melt, burn or are conductive for electrical current.

You will want to print (times are rough estimates for an Anet A6 with all settings set to default):

  • one Support_Ring (4 hours)
  • one Distance_Ring (1 hour) to bring the whole construction away from the ceiling a bit)
  • up to six Arms (2 hours each)

What else is needed?

  • zipties and/or screws to secure the twigs in the arms (ziptie method shown in the photos)
  • two device screws for mounting the construction below the ceiling (or other screws if you improvise for a missing socket)
  • twigs or other cantilevered things to hold you mobile-things (maximum diameter is 16 mm)

The assembled construction has a total diameter of 30 cm (10 cm center + 2 x 10 cm arm). The whole construction including the twigs on the photos have roughly a diameter of 150 - 180 cm. It feels stable enough for a good amount of decoration, but always check your gut feeling! The clamps holding arms are only designed to be stable in one direction. never bend them upwards or they might break.

I'm fairly new to 3D-printing and this is my first thing designed by myself. I'd be happy to get some feedback :)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20 % (doesn't matter much)

Notes:

Everything is pretty standard:

I printed everything with cheap white PLA (200 °C) on a heated bed (50 °C).

Every part is oriented upside-down. I.e. your printer's bed reflects the later ceiling. The side facing towards the ceiling might look quite coarse because of some flat slopes and the supports that are to be removed.

The arms are easy to remove from the bed, but the center support and the distance ring were a bit harder to get off the painter's tape.

The holes in the parts' wall in some of my pictures were caused by an accidental single-wall setting in the slicer - the default values would have been right. This didn't notably affect the stability.
