comments.author: ChristianSi

comments.text:
So how you, specifically, are giving back to those who prior work you use: maxbots, Kliment, josefprusa etc.? Open source hardware doesn't enforce giving back a part of the income you make based on the concepts from others to them, that's true, but it certainly doesn't prevent it. Those who want to behave ethically will openly share their own ideas and honor the unwritten rules of open source, see http://makezine.com/2012/02/14/soapbox-the-unspoken-rules-of-open-source-hardware/http://makezine.com/2012/02/14...
Those who want to behave like assholes, on the other hand, cannot be stopped by licensing. Even NC cannot prevent others from building and selling an NC-licensed printer, since licenses are based on copyright, and copyright doesn't apply to physical things. So if I download an NC-licensed STL, I'm not allowed to resell the STL, but I'm allowed to print it and then sell the printed part, since copyright doesn't apply here. (Just like most cookbooks are copyrighted and restaurants can still use them to prepare and then sell their dishes.) Of course, those who are fair and honor the intent of others wouldn't do it, but there is no way to stop the bad guys. Except for community blame-and-shame, with can be effective for true open source hardware as well.
But the really bad thing about NC, besides not working as you think it works, it that it creates a lose-lose situation where cooperation becomes entirely impossible. If others (besides the original license holder) contribute an improved derivation to an NC project, the result is a work which NOBODY is allowed to use commercially (since nobody owns full copyright to the resulting work and hence can ignore the license terms). Hence, there has never been a successful cooperative project that uses NC licenses, while the open source (mostly GPL'd) RepRap project is flourishing, with an amazing amount of contributors (both individuals and companies) sharing their improvements and thus creating a result that is much better than anything a company or individual could have accomplished by themselves.
So, please be considered towards yourself as well as towards others, and change the license.

title: Orange Pi Zero Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a case for the Orange Pi Zero: http://www.orangepi.org/orangepizero/
Specifically, the original Orange Pi Zero with the H2+ CPU.

CAUTION:

  • This will not fit the Orange Pi Zero Plus2 (with the HDMI connector). It might fit the Orange Pi Zero Plus with the H5 CPU, but I don't have one to try.
  • This case is for the Orange Pi Zero only, without the interface expansion board.

If you do print this, consider the staggering amount of good karma that will come from providing feedback here. Even a short comment will do wonders.

OpenSCAD source shared in case you would like to make changes. Please respect the CC license. Source is also shared on github: https://github.com/phildubach/OrangePiZeroCase

The Orange Pi Zero that was used for taking measurements has its USB-A socket soldered in at a slight angle. I'm not sure whether that's the case for all units. However, even the one pictured at the orangepi site shows the USB connector slightly angled. If yours is straight, you might have to modify the source and generate a new STL for the bottom shell.
All connectors and the SD card slot have 0.5mm clearance, which is hopefully enough to make up for any tolerances.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

150um

Infill:

20%

Notes:
  • Print bottom shell with supports, but only allow supports from build plate. Bridges should not need any support, but the holes for the screw heads do.
  • Diameters for small holes can be tricky. If the M3 screws don't fit, change hole_d in OrangePiZero_lid.scad.

Assembly
  • The Orange Pi fits pretty snugly into the bottom shell. Insert the end with the USB and Ethernet connectors first. Then flex the shell a tiny bit while pushing the PCB into place.
  • Unplug the antenna and thread the connector through the center hole of the lid, before plugging it in again. This is easier than trying to push most of the antenna through from the bottom.
  • Requires M3x8mm machine screws. Longer screws work fine, too.

OpenSCAD

All measurements are in variables at the top of the files, so minor customization should be simple.

description.text:
This is my very first thingy I am publishing on Thingiverse! Whoa!

Description:
I created this box for a family member requesting a way to organize her essential oils. The box holds sixteen 10 mL bottles. It will most likely organize anything smaller than that, I do know that the 30 mL or larger bottles will not fit.

The lid is a snug fit that slides smoothly within the box body. I added magnets to the lid and box to help keep the lid secure when closed. The magnet is a 6x2 cylinder, I will add a link.

Changes I'd Like To Make:

  • Make the knob apart of the lid, instead of two separate pieces
  • Create a better housing for the magnets
  • Make the dividers customizable, so the user can organize as they wish

Please provide constructive feedback. Thank you and happy printing!

author: runaway380

description.text:
In honor of the 2018 Winter Olympics here is my take on model designed to print well at scale and with minimal support.

There are three parts to the model that must be assembled and were designed in a way that allowed the handle to be printed in a different color.

Assembly:

  • Glue the fastener to the bottom of the handle
  • Turn handle onto stone
  • Profit!!

Enjoy! Go Team USA!!

Print flat side down.

Supports: No

Infill: 5-20% depending on scale

Known Issues

  • Overhang prints OK on my printer, may update the model to reduce the angle.

This is the only part that needs supports. With some fine tuning you may be able to remove the supports, but for ease of printing it is a good idea.

Supports: Yes

Infill: 10%

This part is optional if you were to glue the handle to the stone directly.

Another option would be to design the handle to accept threads with a through bolt from the bottom, much luck an actual curling stone. I didn't go this route simply because I wanted to be able to scale this to any percentage and not have to worry about finding screws that would fit each print.

description.text:
These are the parts for the next iteration of my E3D adapter.
Goals
Refresh the design to use v6 heatbreak, dual material with ability to independently level nozzle height, maintain same Z height as stock, and 1.75 filament option.

First run of machined aluminum parts can be found here.

Notes:

Mounting plate with integrated air guide for E3D adapter, I recommend using Polycarbonate.
.
Blower shroud is designed for radial fan found here here and for heat set brass insets

Lever arm, is for UM2+ styled extruder and replaces stock arm, this shifts the bearing 1.2mm closer to the drive gear enabling 1.75mm filament to be driven, recommend using Polycarbonate.

To convert to 1.75 diameter filament, sleeve the 6mm ptfe bowden tube using 2mm ID x 3mm OD tubing, this can be found on aliexpress. you will need to fabricate a plug to prevent the sleeve from being pulled back into the extruder. The plug 3d file is on my todo list.

title: CR-10S Filament Sensor Cable Clip Piggyback Cover

description.text: This is technically a remix but the original parts are not hosted on Thingiverse. I found an excellent combined filament sensor and extruder cover for my CR-10S entitled "CR-10 Bowden with sensor box,cover and spring arm" by bruce falkenstein85 on Tinkercad at https://www.tinkercad.com/things/42gI8bRGpPh-cr-10-bowden-with-sensor-boxcover-and-spring-arm What I like about his design is that it fits the CR-10S' stock filament sensor switch perfectly and his filament guide holes are lined up so well that it doesn't require any fishing when loading filament. I used everything except Mr. Falkenstein's extended tension arm as the CR-10S's stock arm seemed a little stronger with its embedded nut but I really liked the cable clip at the end of his extended arm as my hot end umbilical seems to always want to lie right over the extruder. I designed this little cable clip cover that piggybacks on top of Mr. Falkenstein's filament sensor cover. I originally modified the stl incorporating my clip directly onto his cover put it was difficult to get a nice print using supports on such a small piece so I just modeled a separate piece piggybacked on top. I had to use M3x8mm screws for the slightly increased thickness. Also if you use this do not overtighten the screws as they don't fit very tightly to begin with and can strip the plastic easily. They don't require much torque anyway since they're just holding the cover on.

Printer:

Creality CR-10S

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

100%

description.text:
Sombra's EMP from Overwatch! This has been built to house LEDs. The files with "light" in the name should be printed with a transparent filament if you are going to utilize LEDs.

The backing pieces should be attached together as one piece, which may require some additional support. The backing is designed to be removable via screwing into the rest of the unit using M3 screws with matching heat-set inserts. You can find these at the following links:

  • https://www.mcmaster.com/#94180A333
  • https://www.mcmaster.com/#92005A124

You probably won't need to heat-set the inserts, but you will want to secure them using epoxy or some other adhesive.

Minor disclaimer: While I have fully printed this, I haven't finished assembling and painting due to other projects that have come up. I will likely offer some revisions in the future but wanted to get this out there.

Known future revisions:

  • Better backplate that doesn't require manual reinforcement

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This is a relatively straight forward print that should be good up to 0.2mm resolution. You will need supports, and I highly recommend using PVA water soluble supports for this.

When printing the lights, you may want to make the lights thinner to let more light through. In Cura you can do this by unchecking "Uniform Scaling" and then making it smaller on the Z-Axis.

The Silver 1 piece, due to its odd shape, will probably be the hardest to print. It has a large wall around it to reduce light pollution from the dark purple LEDs but is also hollowed out to make room for the light pink LEDs.

Lastly, most of the pieces should have a bit of clearance build in (0.1-0.2mm) built in. You will probably still need to do some sanding to ensure everything fits correctly based on how accurate your printer is.

Pre-Assembly

I've included images from Fusion 360 that show what each assembled piece should look like before painting. For adhesive you should use epoxy or some other adhesive that is strong and works on plastic.

At this point you will want to manually reinforce the purple backing with a small sheet of plastic or wood. Due to the way it was designed it's relatively weak in the middle. I plan on fixing this at a later date.

Painting

At this point you should smooth the surface and paint the parts. Since the parts have largely been separated based on colour, there should be minimal masking needed.

If you want to use basic LEDs, you will want to tint/dye the transparent pieces so that they emit pink and purple colour. Otherwise you can skip this if you're going to use something like neo pixels.

Heat Set Inserts

At this point you should install the heat set inserts. The holes for them are slightly bigger than the parts, which will necessitate using epoxy or super glue to keep the inserts in place.

Final Assembly

At this point you will glue all of the remaining pieces together. You will want to assemble the silver pieces and LEDs first before attaching the silver pieces to the purple pieces. Do not glue the backplate to the purple piece, it will be attached with screws.

Lighting

Since the back comes off, you can add the LEDs and electronics at your leisure. Please note that there is a hole hidden in the side for a switch so you don't need to take the backplate off every time you want to turn the lights off.

Attach to costume

I would attach snap buttons or velcro to the back side so that the EMP can be easily removed for when you need to access the batteries.

title: Feedback bike repair stand adjustment knob enbigerator

description.text:
I've always hated the wing nut on the vertical adjustment of my Feedback folding mechanics stand. It takes a good deal of force to keep it from sliding down and some times a painful amount of torque to turn it loose.

This part makes the wingnut a lot easier to turn. It's a very tight press fit, I had to beat it on. There's a slight taper to the wingnut slot to help.

My work stand is an older model that looks similar to the current Sport-Mechanic model but it's not a one hundred percent match. Wouldn't surprise me if several models use the same wingnut. Also wouldn't surprise me if Feedback changed their supplier at some point and this doesn't work at all for others.

description.text:
Ever felt outgunned by those filthy air blasters while using your Caliburn? Ever felt like you could handle a heavier spring?

Enter the K14, a 24.9kg spring with a length perfectly suited to the Caliburn. With this kit you can double the spring power of your Caliburn, increasing FPS significantly. To fit this spring and provide proper alignment three printed pieces are necessary, which I print at 50% infill in PLA. I also use an X-Profile O-Ring which is wonderful for improving the stock seal of your Caliburn's ramrod.

Kits and Springs are available at my Etsy shop if you don't have a printer or need a spring: https://www.etsy.com/shop/Remzak?ref=l2-shopheader-name

To install the kit, just replace the three stock printed pieces with their similar looking reshaped counterparts, install the spring, and the new O-Ring. I recommend doubling the O-Rings on your plunger piece for an improved seal, and doubling the small O-Rings on the ram to improve the seal there. A Longer barrel or tighter barrel is a necessity, without them you will be seriously under utilizing the spring and risking major damage.

WARNING: This spring induces increased stress on all parts of your Caliburn, specifically the spreader from my conversations with CaptainSlug. I have not broken, damaged, or seen stress marks on my stock spreader (PLA 100% Infill) through hundreds of shots, but know that it is an inherent risk. If using this kit you should be using an upgraded barrel (your own/sold separately) to utilize the power, which will help protect the plunger. Using this kit with darts that are a loose fit in the stock barrel will induce unnecessary wear. Early iterations of this kit had trouble with the catch slipping, since implementing version 3 of the design I have had no issues. If you have issues a tight rubber band around the rear of the sear solved any problems I had with early parts. This is a crazy strong spring, use at your own risk.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Should be fine without supports if your printer is okay at bridging.

Works best with 3-4 balls per barrel, producing a large spread of balls. Proceed to have fun.

description.text:
This fishing rod holder can be mounted on a wall or ceiling or boat at any angle. The STL file includes 2 mirrored parts which together make one rod-holder capable of storing 4 fishing rods. This model is 270mm wide and will not fit on smaller beds.

The three horizontal holes are for mounting. The 2 vertical holes are for shock-cord. The shock cord is not needed but I would recommend for use in a boat. To use, feed one piece of shock-cord through both holes and tie off so they won't pull back through. Then use the rod tip to push the shock cord back towards the rear or up (depending on how it was mounted). Once the rod-tip is in place the shock-cord will apply pressure to keep the tip in one of the notches.

description.text:
Score keeper for billiards & pool. Keep track of up to # innings, or play first to # against someone else, etc.

If you'd like to print in two colors, print separately and pause at Z 2mm on the bookend, and 3mm on the counter piece to switch plastic. Would be really cool to see someone print a corresponding color for each ball! I used a sharpie to blacken one of the bookend's white stripe - black side being solids, striped side's, well, you know...

You'll need four bookends - glue a set of bookends together, back to back, smooth side.
Choose how many ever counter pieces you'd like,I used 9 for mine.

To finish, you'll need some sort of 3mm diameter tube to attach the bookends together. I used a 3mm carbon fiber rod and then a couple of drops of CA on both sides of each end to lock it down tight, worked great (may need a very slight reaming if too tight).

Hope you enjoy!

title: Keystone adapter for Alumbra Siena phone wall plates

description.text:
All wallplates in my home are from Alumbra Siena. While this is a good line and they do have an ethernet jack module (RJ45), this particular module is very overpriced.

But they do have a reasonably priced phone jack that is just slightly bigger than a standard keystone.

So I ordered some cheap Ethernet keystones from China and a bunch of Alumbra phone modules, and designed this little adapter to join both.

Just remove the RJ11 plug, snap it into it's place and attach a keystone module inside.

(Keep in mind that Alumbra Sienas actually has different types of phone modules. My picture there are actually 2 different types, the one with a larger slot has been replaced with an adapter + RJ45 jack, and the smaller one was left with the original RJ11 jack)

But may also fit the 600 or A500 .

title: Anet A8 Bowden Extruder Mount for top spoolholder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For those of you who swapped for bowden extruder with the Anet A8 and have a top spoolholder

I use this one https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1624641

Make sure that if you don't use this spoolholder, the bars around the anet a8 frame must not be over 11mm for each side. (Width)

WHAT YOU NEED
M3-2x30mm screws (I found extras from my anet a8 kit)(They need to be exactly 30)
They will hold the extruder to the P2 and the stock anet a8 spring thingy)
M3-2x45mm or more(If you still have them, use the old hex screws that were holding the extruder fan+radiator from the stock anet extruder)
Those will hold the P1 to the anet a8 frame, next to the LCD display.
M3-1x19mm or more
This screw will hold P1 to P2.

Instructions: Place part 1 in part 2. Screw them together.
Remove the 2 screws already in place holding the left side of the lcd display of the Anet A8.
Screw the part 1 and part2 next to the LCD board using the 45mm+ m3.
It should not move or wiggle.
Place the bottom part of the stock anet a8 extruder and use the 30mm screws to fix it.
Dont forget to place the spring
Screw the extruder to extruder with the bottom anet a8.

It should be just next to the spool holder you have.

If you have issues comment!
Thanks

Notes:

Use the orientations shown.

Assembly:

Print 4 Cogs, 2 Guides, 2 Braces, 4 20mm Pins, 2 12mm pins, and 1 of everything else.

Refer to the exploded view here: https://youtu.be/mUq02HKfeVU

The chain is in two print-in-place pieces, gently break each link free if needed and work them until they move freely. Assemble the two different lengths by clipping them together with the hooks facing out.

Assemble the front of the blade using a piece of 1.75mm filament as a pin between the guide parts. Press 12mm pins in both sides, make sure they are aligned properly and firmly snap them together.

Slip the cover piece onto the blade (it has a subtle top and bottom) and mount the blade into the top case with two 20mm pins.

Position the bottom case and snap on the cover and handle. Affix the handle with another pair of 20mm pins.

The pins can be a bit finicky, you can use M4 hardware instead.

About:

I was playing around with the Fusion 360 renderer and ended up with the image below. I thought I would see if I could make a printable version. Note the teeth are not on the chain in the included STL files, still having some issues getting them to work out right.

title: OpenAPS edison-explorer rig case for 18650 (pre-wired ~70mm batteries)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a minimal case (as in small, compact, thin) for OpenAPS edison/explorer rig with a 18650 battery (amazon: http://a.co/avLESoe - this one requires soldering a jst-ph connector on*, I used one from an old battery, but these may work: http://a.co/9ooVhXm). It should also fit similar batteries that are pre-wired and are under ~72mm long and 19mm diameter (including wire bumps). It's more like a skin than a case, so don't expect it to save the rig from falls or rough handling... no warranty express or implied ;)

The cover locks on with a M2 screw (I used a 6mm one but you could probably do with a shorter one).

The wires need to be curled in with the board or above it under the cover. There's not much room so go slow and be careful.

Note: I have the older version thin explorer boards but I think I left room for the new ones, let me know.

Bonus: there's a hole right over the reset button and it looks actually reachable/usable ;).

Update: the V2 files add a few tabs with a hook that will keep the cover on a bit better, and improved the reset hole, added a few more vent holes over the edison.

Footnote: * It's my understanding the explorer does not have protection for reversing the voltage, so if you solder your own connector be very careful to get the polarity correct. This pre wired battery should be correct: https://www.adafruit.com/product/1781

description.text: This is a library for manipulating and visualizing 3D vectors in OpenSCAD. It has basic functions like crossProduct_3DVector() and magnatude_3DVector() as well as some more complex functions to test vector angles and rotate one vector towards another vector. Check out the instructions tab to see more detail.

To use it in your own project, download the .scad and put it in your openscad library folder or in the same folder as the project you are using it in. Then at the top of your script just type : use <3dvector.scad> We've also included this in Customizer! Include it in your customizers by typing: use <utils/3dvector.scad> Here'Âs a full list of the functions and modules included: function magnatude_3DVector(v)
give this function a 3D vector in [x,y,z] format and it will return the length of that vector function angleBetween_3DVector(u, v)
give this function two 3D vectors in [x,y,z] format and it will return the angle, in degrees, between them function normalize_3DVector(v)
give this function a 3D vector in [x,y,z] format and it will return a vector that points in the same direction but with a length of 1 function dotProduct_3DVector(u, v)
give this function two 3D vectors in [x,y,z] format and it will return the dot product of those vectors function crossProduct_3DVector(u, v)
give this function two 3D vectors in [x,y,z] format and it will return the cross product of those vectors function rotMatrix_3DVector(axis, angle)
give this function a 3D vectors in [x,y,z] format for axis and an angle in degrees and it will return a rotation matrix for the axis-angle rotation function rotAxisAngle_3DVector(vec, axis, angle)
give this function an initial 3D vector and a 3D vector for the axis in [x,y,z] format, and an angle in degrees and it will return the rotated vector function trackTo_3DVector(cur, tar, influence)
give this function an initial 3D vector and a target 3D vector in [x,y,z] format, then give it an influence between 0 and 1 and it will return an interpolated vector between the two vectors according to the influence function random_3DVector(seed = undef)
calling this function without any parameters will return a random 3D vector. pass it a seed value to get the same "random" vector each time module drawArrow_3DVector ( vector = [10, 10, 10], root = [0, 0, 0], color_from_magnatude = true, magnatude_range = 100, radius_from_magnatude = true, manual_radius = 1, res = 16 ) this module will draw a colored arrow to represent a 3D Vector.
root controls where the vector starts from.
magnatude_range defines the vector length that will result in a purple arrow. Vectors approaching 0 length will be red.
radius_from_magnatude controls if the arrow gets fatter when it is longer.
manual_radius controls the radius if radius_from_magnatude is set to false.
res is the number of facets around the arrow. module drawArrowChain_3DVector ( my_vectors = [[10,10,10],[-10,10,10]], root = [0, 0, 0], iterations_left ) this module will recursively draw a chain of colored arrows end to end to represent a list of 3D Vectors.
root controls where the vector chain starts from.
iterations_left controls how many more recursions will occur, this parameter will self populate and only needs to be exposed because of how recursion works in OpenSCAD. Don'Ât set this unless you have a good reason to.

title: Crypt Board Game
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Crypt: Monster and magic in a dungeon you create! Designed by Patrick Rael.
In Crypt, players take on the role of evil wizards who control competing monster forces, which move about in a dungeon that constantly grows. Each turn, a player may take one of three actions: lay a tile which expands the dungeon, move a monster in his force, or cast a magic spell. The objective is to move your monsters into enemy Crypts.

Monsters begin the game in their home Crypt. Each has a strength and movement rating. Strong monsters are slow, weak ones fast. Which will you play early and which will you save for later? Which will you use to defend, and which will seek entry into enemy Crypts?

Dungeon tiles are used to build the dungeon. Lay them carefully to block monsters from entering your Crypt, and make entryways into enemy Crypts.

Spell tiles keep things interesting. Poisons lower abilities; Potions raise them. A Reaper could mean instant death, while a Seraph returns you safely to your Crypt. Traps stop movement, while a Ghost lets you walk through walls. Or use Transporters to pop up in unexpected places. Suffering under an enemy spell? Remove it with a Zapper.

Crypt is an easily-learned, quick-playing tile-laying game suitable for 2-4 players Ages 8 and up.

I have remixed several pieces into the player pawns. As the Crypt is a large room you will need to print this tile 3 times for a small crypt and 6 times for a full crypt.

author: Bolivian86

print_settings.Notes:: This should be really easy to print, as there is good bottom surface on the bed.  The supports are only needed on the Part 1, depending on how your printer handles overhangs and vertical holes.   If you have a slicer that allows variable settings (i.e. Simplify 3D) you can start printing the second part at ~20% infill at the 3.063MM (0.125") height. This will save a considerable amount of time, as the motor brace does not need all that much infill. The actual mounting point should be printed at 100% infill, so do not print the whole part at 20%.

description.text:
This was inspired by s_gutz's direct drive extruder mount, and I decided to try my own take on it. I wanted to use as many stock parts as possible and not lose any bed space.

The mount also includes a mount for a 18mm Sensor. I use capacitive for glass but inductive will fit just as well if it is 18mm. The offsets for the probe is -50MM X and -10MM Y. Lookup how to set these in your printer firmware, although it is not necessary if you do not have a Z probe.

UPDATE (2/23/18)

The final files for version 2 is updated with fixed clearances. I also removed the now obsoleted version 1

UPDATE (2/21/18)

The version 2 design works well enough, however it has a few clearance issues. The 18MM probe is quite tight, but will fit with a little coaxing. The angles to brace the stepper motor are off, so they will need to be sanded or clipped off. Both of these will be updated soon! It is still vastly better than the first version.

UPDATE (2/19/2018)

I have uploaded the files for the two part design!! It has the 18MM mount, a brace for the motor, ziptie mounts for the wires, and it's now flat printable. The only caveat is this version is untested, however it is currently being made on my printer.

Printer:

Creality CR10S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2MM

Infill:

100%

Notes:

This should be really easy to print, as there is good bottom surface on the bed. The supports are only needed on the Part 1, depending on how your printer handles overhangs and vertical holes. If you have a slicer that allows variable settings (i.e. Simplify 3D) you can start printing the second part at ~20% infill at the 3.063MM (0.125") height. This will save a considerable amount of time, as the motor brace does not need all that much infill. The actual mounting point should be printed at 100% infill, so do not print the whole part at 20%.

To install you must use M3x9 or similar screws for the fan mount and M3x20 or similar for the actual hot end. All other hardware is stock.

If you want to make the fit between the parts rock solid, even though the setup is already pretty nice with the tight friction fit, add a little super glue in the slot before putting the parts together. MAKE SURE THE PARTS ARE FULLY SEATED BEFORE THE GLUE SETS!!!

In order to determine how much PTFE tube you need, put one end in the hotend and mark it, put the other end in the extruder and mark it. Measure the marks and add them, mine was ~65mm but I would double check yours to be sure.

You might have to crack open the case in order to re-wire a few motors. I actually used the second Z-axis wire and swapped it with the extruder wire. Be sure you double check everything before engaging the motors

comments.text: The V2 looks like the extruder mounting bracket isn't actually secured to the hot end mounting bracket in any way other than a friction fit? That seems like it might work fine and might unexpectedly (say, when a nozzle jams or you're printing at high speeds) cause the extruder, motor and all, to come crashing down onto your build plate mid-print...
comments.author: MrJelle

comments.text: You are completely correct, there is only a friction fit. However the actual PTFE tube is able to clamp the whole thing down. If you are super worried, super glue will work too. Even so, I think the filament is more likely to grind instead of lifting up the bracket.

[Updated: 03-03-2018]
The MimiMasterSpool Is currently in a very usable state. I have updated the bottom and the top to V5 and V6 respectively. There are 3 cable tie ditches available for pulling filament off the spool, or putting it back on. There is a hole through the center to allow for you to insert the end of the filament. There are also 4 filament end storage locations for keeping the end of the filament in a safe spot. this allows for stacking as well. I have thickened the spool ends to reduce flexing when winding or adding filament to the spool.

The Yellow portion was printed on a Prusa I2, the white half was printed on my Mp select Mini V2. Do not use support material at all! if you do you will have a fun time cleaning the threads...

Please let me know if you print this spool, leave any comments and or suggestions.
Thanks.

[Updated: 02-28-2018]
Fusion 360 crashed on me and I lost a few modifications to the spool, I'll have to fire everything back up again and get back to where i was. I'll update as soon as I can.

[Updated : 02-19-2017 9:39PM]
THIS UPDATE HAS NOT BEEN TESTED YET.
I have added end management to the spool, I have also reduced the thickness in some spaces to make for less filament use and quicker print times. currently at 0.3mm layer height and 50mm/s bottom prints at about 2 1/2 hours with no raft. I am in the process of printing MiniMasterSpoolTopV3 and MiniMasterSpoolBottomV2. I will update when I have printed these sets.

[Updated : 02-19-2017 6:14AM]
Spool works, you should be able to print. results may vary by printer.

[Updated : 02-18-2017 10:28PM] WARNING Thing is being test printed right now, Test print threading match, printing V2 of top now. Ill add filament management features soon.

This is a simple battery holder for a pointer style ELT practice beacon. These are used for Search and Rescue training. The unit uses 5 C-batteries that only fit into the case in a pentagonal arrangement. This holder with identical top and bottom allows for the easy replacement of batteries in the unit without having to build a special battery pack or substitute smaller batteries. Print two and wire as per the diagram.

Wiring the battery holder

The holder top and bottom are identical. There is a small tab on one of the cell spaces for alignment. Make sure the tab on the top and bottom holder are on the same battery. You can use paperclip or wires to connect the cell spaces top and bottom. The batteries should go in with + - + - + facing up. The positive lead should attach to the top of the space with the tab. The negative lead should attach to the bottom of the space one counterclockwise of the tab when viewed from the top. I intended the slot to make the contacts more springy but it was not large enough for my printer to render it and it works just fine anyway.

FalloutFalloutFallout!!!! I like FALLOUT!!!! If you have seen any of my other Fallout Yao Guai (Yeti) Rambler Tumbler 20oz handles, well here are more... a lot more. I have included all of my Fallout related handles in one place. More may pop up from time to time, so check back often.

If the name ends in 'EXP', then the design is somewhat experimental. These designs will need support to print properly, as some have an extremely small footprint on the first layer and much of the design will include perimeters that cannot be accomplished with bridging. So if your printer doesn't do well with supports, bridging, overhangs or printing in general, best to not print these designs. Also, there are a lot of designs, I may have forgotten to post renderings of them all, so look through the design files after you download them, or check the Thingiverse renderings. There are 60mm and 40mm Brotherhood of Steel Logo's.

As always, I have included STEP (.stp) source files so these designs can easily be customized and edited. STEP files open in a variety of CAD packages, like AutoDesk's FREE to use Fusion 360.

Enjoy, happy printing, and be careful out there in the wastelands of the post-apocalyptic Commonwealth.

For manipulative learning of time - hours

red for hard engraving and black line for cutting

I recommend covering the surface of the board with masking tape before cutting, when removing it after cutting you will find the surface clean from burns

author: atamblay

description.text:
I took the automatic fish feeder that pefozzy created (thank you!) and tweaked it a little to fit the components I had on hand. Specifically a NANO arduino and a 9g micro servo (SG90). I also added a cap for the food bowl. The design is still a work in progress and has yet to be fully tested with the 3mm hole for portion size for 1 beta. I hope to do this soon.

My daughter has a beta that is close to her heart that I'd like kept alive while we go away for vacation, and hopefully this will do the trick.

https://youtu.be/qMpVXPntwms

With slide for moisture mitigation
https://youtu.be/DxEfcEwWTCU

Materials:

  • Nano Arduino (elegoo in my case)
  • 9g servo & servo horn
  • misc screws

After some insight from the original designer on moisture potentially being a problem with the betta food clogging the hole.
To help solve this problem I've added a raised platform and food slide off at an angle for the delivery. Hopefully with the offset from the feeding opening I won't see the food affected by the moisture as much. Real fish testing still to be done.

**Update
positioned slide over open water of the tank for food delivery for a week, the food didn't absorb any water in the hopper. Seems to be a success so far.

The arduino program for the nano is included in the files. The .ino file.

comments.text: how did you make a such transparent print?
comments.author: dgncsk

comments.text: I posted a couple years back about differences in transparent filaments - http://thrinter.com/10-transparent-filaments/, but I guess I didn't go too much in detail on the settings. For clear prints, I prefer PETG or TPU, printing around 30mm/sec at 100% infill with the part cooling fan at or near 0%. There are quite a few other factors though, I'll try to put up a blog post on thrinter.com sometime that explains it more thoroughly. This was printed in Yasin clear PETG.

NOTE OF CAUTION
Keep an eye on the bottom third of the print and make sure no ventilation features warp up snagging your printer nozzle. Issue Can be prevented by slowing print, reducing layer height, heat or smoothing raised overhang as it shrinks up with a flat piece of cool metal such as a butter knife.
Use self tapping screws to match or drill to match your screws.

Let us know what you think.

print_settings.Notes:: Saddle was printed on end, the other parts were printed with the largest flat side down.  Two sensor brackets were printed for both ends of the angle, one to hold the sensor, the other to keep the ball from falling off.

description.text:
This is a ball balancing test rig for experimenting with PID tuning. PID is a control loop feedback system. A Ping Pong ball is balanced on an aluminum angle. The angle is tipped side to side supported by a pivot. A hobby servo is used to move the angle. The caps on the angle have mounting holes for a Adafruit VL53L0X breakout board (laser distance sensor). Included in the files are the pivot, end caps, and servo base.

The pivot supports a 1", 1/8" thick aluminum angle. My angle is approximately 500mm in length. This length is the maximum reliable range for the VL53L0X using a white ping pong ball target.

Also included are the Fusion 360, and Step design files if you wish to make modifications.

See my instructable project here: https://www.instructables.com/id/Ball-Balancer-and-PID-Fiddler/

Printer:

MP3DP

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Saddle was printed on end, the other parts were printed with the largest flat side down. Two sensor brackets were printed for both ends of the angle, one to hold the sensor, the other to keep the ball from falling off.

Attached the support to the base. This fit snug for me and required no modification or glue.

The saddle pivots on two screws. The support holes were drilled slightly larger for the screws to freely pivot.

The sensor brackets fit snug on the 1/8 thick angle. The sensor is attached with two mounting screws with nuts. The mounting holes are slotted to align with the center of a ping pong ball when mounted to the top of the slots. When mounted to the bottom of the slots, the sensor is aligned to the center of a foose ball. The square slot is aligned with the sensor pins for wiring to the sensor.

A hobby servo is mounted to the servo base, and is free standing. I connected the servo to the sensor bracket with a stiff wire. I drilled a small screw hole for attaching the wire around the screw.

Tips: Paint the inside of the angle with flat black paint to reduce reflection of the VL53L0X laser. This gave me more accurate distance readings. The laser is not a narrow beam, its more like a beam from a flashlight. The light is not visible to the eye, but can be seen using a camera (smart phone) as a monitor.

Place the pivot off center of the aluminum angle so slight force is always down on your servo. This keeps your servo from bouncing up when pulling the angle down.

Remove support structures and try if bottom and top fit easily snapping together. If not, just remove a bit of the snap lid (or whatever you call it) with a sharp knife an d try again. description.text:
I designed this with 3d printers in mind. I made a storage bin that fits into the 5 1/4" bay. This allows you to put 5 SD cards, and 5 Micro SD cards in the bin. Also has room for CD/DVD (system recovery stuff), or you could even put in a USB harddrive (I put in my Western Digital Passport with the cable).

I created another one that's blank without the SD, for those who don't need or want SD storage.

This was designed for use with ABS, but PLA should also be fine!

Hardware needed, but not required.

12x 2mmx2mm magnents (I got mine off ebay or you can order from omomagnets.com)
These are to help keep the drawer shut they go in the 6 holes in the back of the drawer and 6 holes in the receiver. (For those who are afraid of magnets in your computer, if you havent done so take a harddrive apart, those magnets are super freaking strong and they are less than 1/2" from your platters... you never have data problems. Thats typically for tape and floppy discs(Thats the way us IT geeks wipe tapes and discs so they are unrecoverable).

2x 2mm by about 6mm dowl pins to keep the tray from fully coming out. Again this is not required.

2 to 8 standard computer drive screws to secure the drive in place (My case is the C70 by corseair and it has spring loaded pegs to keep the drive in place, but you can add the screws to add additional security.)

Thats pretty much it!

description.text:
Thermal Camera

This Thermal Camera was inspired by the DIY Mini Thermal Camera from Adafruit, based on the 8 x 8 infrared grid array sensor amg8833. This version is based on the cheap ESP8266 and an ILI9341 touch screen. Two software versions are available, one is based to the Adafruit example, the second and more advanced regarding interpolation, is based on the code of Kris Kasprzak. Both were slightly enhanced to provide a portrait screen orientation, a thermal scale, a touch screen autoscale function, a lipo monitoring and a temperature measurement in the center.

By exchanging the micro controller, the total cost of hardware was reduced to around 55€. Since the design was kept simple and the code was available, this was a nice little weekend project.

UPDATE / 22.02.2018

For a new display driver which allows a higher framerate, the pin mapping was updated as well as the arduino sketches. Pin D3 and D8 have been swapped. Faster display driver included for the ESP8266 Wemos D1 Mini or Node MCU. Fixed battery display

https://youtu.be/Us709RQinSo

Printer:

Anycubic Linear Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

35%

Notes:

The parts were designed to be printed without supports, overhangs less than 45° and no part bigger than 100mm to be printable easily.

Instructions

Partlist

  • Wemos D1 Mini (e.g. https://de.aliexpress.com/item/ESP8266-ESP-12-ESP-12F-CH340G-CH340-V2-USB-WeMos-D1-Mini-WIFI-Entwicklungsboard-D1-Mini/32674463823.html)
  • Ili9341 touchscreen display (e.g. https://de.aliexpress.com/item/240x320-2-8-SPI-TFT-LCD-Touch-Panel-Serial-Port-Module-with-PCB-ILI9341-5V-3/32815224002.html)
  • Adafruit amg8833 breakout board (https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-amg8833-8x8-thermal-camera-sensor)
  • 3.7V Lipo battery
  • Wemos battery shield (or another Lipo loader board)
  • 2 pcs. M4 x 10mm flat head screws
  • switch
  • Wires and wire strips
  • 130kOhm resistor

Assembly

The assembly is very simply and consists of the following steps:

  1. Grip is attached to the body by two M4 screws which could be inserted directly to the PLA. The lens hole points to the front.
  2. The lipo, the loading circuit and the used micro controller are mounted with wire strips to the holder with the USB connectors facing to the top for easy loading and flashing. Why wire strips? By this, all different lipos, loader pcbs and different µC controllers could be used
  3. Installation of switch in the housing, it could be glued or screwed
  4. Wiring everything up
  5. The amg8833, the display and the electronics are inserted in the corresponding position
  6. Top is simply clipped in place and could be opened to update the software or to load the lipo

Wiring

See attached screenshot for wiring. For battery monitoring, a 130kOhm resistor connects A0 of the Wemos D1 Mini and Lipo anode.

Software

Two software version are available which could be used, both use the interrupt of the touch screen for user interaction. If a bigger µC (like the teensy 3.2) is used, the touch screen could be used, but the code needs to be enhanced for this feature. Wemos D1 Mini was set to 160MHz in Arduino IDE

Recommended version "ThermalCameraMod" is based on the work of Kris Kasprzak and provides a smooth and fast interpolation algorithm.

Adafruit example sketch for amg8833 with some extensions, this version provides less colors, less resolution but a higher framerate.

Required libraries (Arduino IDE manage libraries):

  • Adafruit AMG88xx Library
  • Adafruit ILI9341
  • Adafruit GFX Library
  • for ESP8266 (folders ending with TFT_eSPI) version, TFT_eSPI ZIP import from (https://github.com/Bodmer/TFT_eSPI)

For ESP8266 versions, uncomment the following lines in User_Setup.h:
define ILI9341_DRIVER

define TFT_CS PIN_D8 // Chip select control pin D8
define TFT_DC PIN_D3 // Data Command control pin
define TFT_RST -1 // Set TFT_RST to -1 if the display RESET is connected to NodeMCU RST or 3.3V

Camera manual

The camera starts after booting with a default temperature range. If the target temperatures do not fit the scale, a tap on the screen searches for the minimum and maximum temperature value and adapts the scale accordingly. A long press on the screen toggles the measurement of the center, the value is an average of the four center pixels from the raw data.

Features:

  • Temperature range ~ 0 - 80°C
  • Framerate up to 10Hz
  • Field of view 60°

title: Timing Belt Holder for 20mm Aluminum Extrusion Rail

description.text:
This is a belt holder for mounting a 6mm-wide timing belt to a 20mm-wide aluminum extrusion rail. Fastens to the rail with an M5 bolt and nut. Belt is fed through the bottom of the mount, back out the front, and clamped by two M3 screws.

Many laser engraver kits use this sort of drive mechanism and they recommend clamping the belt into the rail directly with a screw. This causes uneven tension and unnecessary friction. This clamp allows the belt to be mounted parallel to the direction of movement, for a much smoother motion.

comments.text: Brilliant design. Very effective.

description.text:
I've always found the kindle somewhat uncomfortable to use with one hand, so I made this case with loops on one side of the back for easy one handed reading. This is still a work in progress, but this version is good enough to enjoy using. My idea was to use loops so the kindle can hang from relaxed fingers while your thumb can easily move around to turn the page.

I like to use the middle bar with two fingers above and two fingers below. Or you can put your index finger through the top or bottom ring and grip around the case. All of these positions are much more comfortable to hold than the kindle without this case. The only drawback is that the kindle is no longer flat when resting on its back, or may be the wrong shape to fit in some carrying cases.

I designed this around my hands, which are medium sized. Please let me know how this works with large or small hands and I will try to add extra files to accommodate multiple sized hands if needed. Suggestions are welcome!

Things I still want to add:
Better access to power button, which is half covered by case when on right side.
No access to USB with case on right side (but how often do you really charge this thing?)
A tactile indicator notch for easy location of the page back button area.
Foldable hinge?!

The Kindle Voyage has slightly different dimensions than the Kindle Paperwhite, so I don't know if this case will work for the Paperwhite.

title: Velocity-X drone motor spacer and bumper

description.text:
On my Carbix Velocity-X drones I couldn't tighten the motor plates as I think I had to, because I started bending the motor CF plates thus losing motor alignment. It especially happened in the rear motor plates because I do not mount the rear CF beam for making easy the battery installation. These parts here allowed me to tighten the motors as I wanted and they also act as a bumper plus protect a bit the bottom CF motor plate. Added pluses are that they also give a nice color touch and hide the motor screws and avoid mud to accumulate there too.

  • The '90 deg' part is for when all side beams are present.
  • '135 deg' part is for when one of the beam is missing (rear only in my case).

description.text:
Hey'o

Just a 5000x5000x200µm tile (5x5x0.2mm) for bed levelling and Z height calibration.

In your slicer program, set first layer to 0.2mm, just stick one near each levelling screw (allowing for the skirting run), print, peel off with a sharpish thingy and measure with Vernier calipers.

For those without Vernier calipers, a visual guide:
If it doesn't extrude, you may have a clog, or you're too low.
If you see sharp convex ridges on the finish, you're a little too low.
If you see round concave ridges, you're maybe okay, maybe a little high.
If you see gaps in the infill and perimeters, you're too high (or your extrusion is out, check thickness in this case).
Smooth finish/small sharp ridges = perfect!

M3 screws: 1/4 turn = 150µm.
Others: Check the pitch.

Good luck!

remixed_from.title: Pitan (as in printed Titan :-) Geared Extruder

description.text:
In case you, like me, happen to have 625zz bearings laying around instead of 695zz and would rather use them then buy new bearings...

Body and Cover (plus mirrored parts), opened up for 625zz bearings.

Notes:
If installed from the front, the m3x10 bolt for the idler bearing will crash into the cover-side 625zz blocking the idler from putting pressure on the filament. Just install the m3x10 from the back and this problem goes away. The shorter the screw-head the better.

Also, because the 625zz bearing is 5mm thick instead of 4mm, to keep the filament aligned with your mk8 bearing, the motor-side 625zz and large gear need to be installed to be about 1mm closer to the motor and there might not be enough room to install the small gear that much deeper on the shaft (for me everything fit fine).

In case you have an issue, I included a slightly thinned down the large gear (on each side 0.5mm removed, so 1mm thinner in total), so it only moves about 0.5mm closer to the motor and the small gear only needs to be installed 0.5mm deeper on the shaft (there definitely should be room for this).

I use this with this printed groove mount adapter
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2693024/#files

and the nut from here
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1993384/#files

Thanks to ccarrasco :o) I used your mount.
The thing is just a bit lighter, but IMHO stable enough.

4 grams

Hans

Edit: Just added two more versions. Check out which one siuts you best. Small ones are around 4 grams, the bigger one about 6,5. Flat ones don't need support for the arcs.

title: Crosshairs Board Game
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Designed by Stephen Tavener, Artist Néstor Romeral Andrés, Stephen Tavener
Publisher's website https://nestorgames.com
Crosshairs is a combinatorial game with a strong WW1 aerial combat theme. Players each have a squadron of planes and move all of their planes each turn. Movement consists of either
a) a straight pass flight (no altitude change)
b) a climb (increasing the height of the piece by adding an additional ring) or
c) a dive (losing height to make a sequence of moves by removing one ring per descent height).
Pieces are captured when they are in the line of fire of two or more enemy planes. Clouds block line of fire and provide strategic cover during play.

If a player is reduced to having only one plane, he's shot from the sky (i.e., is eliminated from the game). A player wins when he reduces the only remaining opponent to only one plane. Games are brutal, fast, and fun.

description.text:
This is a replacement bearing and motor holder for the Z axis of a CNC 2417 Router. Specifically it hold 2 - 8mm x 15mm x 45mm linear bearings, the drive screw nut and a 42mm dia motor.
From the photos you can see where my original part failed, a weakness due to the screw holes along with a low percentage fill caused it to break at the thinnest part.
Getting the correct measurements for bearing centres etc. wasn't difficult, I've included my measurements on here so you can see if they are the same as yours. Careful measurement of the Z axis holder with the two 8mm shafts in place have resulted in these sizes. I measured the outside size of the 8mm rods along with the inside size and subtracted 8mm to give me the distance between centres. This was done several times at both ends of the Z axis holder where the rods poke out. My size is 38.50mm and works for my machine. My drawing have been produced on Fusion 360 and I've incuded the Fusion 360 file as well so if you want to put it apart and pull your own hole centres etc. in it feel free.
I haven't put holes for screws to hold the nearings in place as I feel that with the motor in place and screws tightened to hold it the bearings with be secure. If they loosen I'll drill and tap a small hole at the back of each bearing and add a grub screw to hold them.
The bearing holes are an accurate 15mm dia, My printer seems to produce slightley smaller holes so when the print was complete I used a 15mm drill bit and ran it through the printed hole to clean it out.
The holes for the screws and bolts holding the drive screw nut are printed at 2mm dia and will need drilling out to match whatever size screws you are using.
You will need 2 M4 x 20mm bolts and matching nuts to tighten everything up and hold the motor in place. There is a recess for the nuts to hold them when tightening.

description.text:
Designed by Cameron Browne, Stephen Tavener, Artist Néstor Romeral Andrés
Publisher https://nestorgames.com
Mutton is a game of bluff, deduction, and berserk farmers with AK-45s.
The wolves have infiltrated the flock; in deep disguise, they start eating the sheep one by one. Can the farmer with his trusty rifle find and kill the wolves, before all the sheep be reduced to mutton?
Each game is played in two rounds, with the players taking turns to be the wolf player. The wolf player who kills the most sheep wins.

print_settings.Notes:: Print up-side-down in the top end to give the clip more strength.

description.text: Problem: I went to Europe about a year an a half ago carrying a 6600 Belkin Backup Battery, and I got annoyed having to try and hold the phone and battery when I need to use the phone and charge it at the same time. Solution: Create a phone case and battery clip in one. I redesigned and TOPEAK Ridecase and added the clip. the battery slides in from either end and is held in place by two ridges.

Printer Brand:

Up!

Printer:

Up Plus2

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print up-side-down in the top end to give the clip more strength.

Step 1:

Find and/or draw your phone and battery to scale.
I used Fusion 360 because its much easier to create editable solids that can be modified later.
I found a good set of iPhone 6 specification and draw the phone myself.
The battery I draw from scratch and ransacked other people electronics modes to get the USB ports to make it look a little more real.

Step 2:

Create several duplicates of your original components, because these next step get destructive.
Shell outwards 2mm both the phone and the battery and subtract the original to create the casings (you may want the shell the original to be subtracted by about 0.10mm-0.20mm to give a bit of clearance in you casing.
and create a blank to subtract for the opening (this you will to trial and error, too tight and the case will break getting the phone in and our).
Chamfer the entry to make it easier to get the phone in and out.

Step 3:

Add the ports and merge the phone case and clip.
Trim up the clip and blend onto the phone case.
Add ridges to hold the battery in place.
Remove some of the case back to make it a little more flexible and to be able to push the phone out (otherwise it extremely difficult to get the phone out without breaking the case.

Step 4:

Print the case standing up with the top edge facing down.
This will give the battery clip more strength. and less chance of one of the wings snapping off.
Print solid off course and with 10% support, just to stop the overhang from drooping.
I printed in 0.10 res to give the curved edges more definition and look a bit neater.
